dialogue:
Doctor: Hello! I see that you were referred to our hospital for a lung adenocarcinoma measuring 28 mm in your right upper lobe. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: We have planned a UVATS procedure to resect the tumor. Are you familiar with this procedure?
Patient: Not really, can you explain it to me?
Doctor: Of course. During the procedure, you will be placed in the left lateral decubitus position under general anesthesia. We will then make a 4-cm skin incision for the main port in the sixth intercostal space at the anterior axillary line.
Patient: Okay, I see.
Doctor: A wound retractor will be used to allow the insertion of a flexible thoracoscope, endoscopic autosuturing device, and vessel-sealing device via the main port incision. This will also allow us to extract the specimen after the operation.
Patient: Hmm, I understand.
Doctor: During the operation, we found an incomplete interlobar fissure between the upper and middle lobe, as well as abnormal lobulation of the upper lobe. Therefore, we carried out a modified marionette technique.
Patient: What does that involve?
Doctor: First, an Internal organ retractor was inserted into the thoracic cavity using a clip applier. This allowed the retractor to grasp the targeted lung parenchyma properly.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: Second, we prepared two sets of looped 1-0 nylon-threaded 18-gauge injection needles. These needles were optimally pierced through the thoracic wall separately.
Patient: And then what happened?
Doctor: Finally, both ends of the 1-0 nylon thread attached to the Internal organ retractor were pulled out through the looped nylon. This allowed us to perform the procedure more effectively.
Patient: I see. So, what are the follow-up requirements for this procedure?
Doctor: You will need regular check-ups and monitoring to ensure that the tumor has been completely removed and that there are no complications. We will provide you with more information regarding your follow-up appointments.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate the explanation.
Doctor: You're welcome! If you have any more questions, feel free to ask. We're here to help.
Patient: I think I understand everything now. Thanks again.
Doctor: No problem, take care, and we'll see you at your follow-up appointment.
soap:
S: The patient confirmed a diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe, measuring 28 mm. The patient expressed unfamiliarity with the planned UVATS procedure and required explanation about the process and follow-up care.
O: During the UVATS procedure, an incomplete interlobar fissure between the upper and middle lobe and abnormal lobulation of the upper lobe were noted. A modified marionette technique was utilized involving the insertion of an internal organ retractor and the use of looped 1-0 nylon-threaded 18-gauge injection needles. The patient was placed in the left lateral decubitus position, and a 4-cm skin incision was made in the sixth intercostal space at the anterior axillary line for the main port.
A: Primary diagnosis is lung adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe. The UVATS procedure was completed with modifications due to anatomical variations. The assessment during surgery did not indicate any immediate complications from the procedure.
P: The patient is scheduled for regular follow-up appointments to monitor for complete tumor removal and to check for any postoperative complications. The patient will be provided with detailed information regarding the schedule and nature of these follow-ups. Further education on the procedure and postoperative care will be provided as needed to ensure understanding and compliance.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello! You mentioned that you came in for an evaluation and treatment for eyebrow alopecia. Can you tell me more about that and if you've experienced any other hair loss on your body?
Patient: Hi, doctor. Yes, I've noticed my eyebrows have been thinning, but I haven't experienced hair loss anywhere else on my body.
Doctor: Alright. Have you done anything to your eyebrows in the past, like plucking them with tweezers?
Patient: Yes, I used to shape my eyebrows by plucking them with tweezers.
Doctor: Do you have any other medical conditions or concerns that you'd like me to be aware of?
Patient: No, I don't have any other medical conditions.
Doctor: Okay, let me examine your eyebrows and other areas on your body to check for any signs of alopecia. *Examines patient* I see sparse and thin black hairs on your eyebrows but no signs of hair loss elsewhere, such as your frontal hairline or temporal area. 
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: Based on my examination, I'm diagnosing you with idiopathic eyebrow hypotrichosis. I'm going to prescribe you a bimatoprost 0.03% solution to apply to the affected areas daily. 
Patient: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: Just so you know, improvement in your eyebrow hypotrichosis will be gradual, so you'll need to be patient. I'd like to see you for periodic follow-up visits every two months to monitor your progress.
Patient: Alright, that sounds reasonable.
Doctor: *During follow-up visits* How has your compliance with the daily application of the bimatoprost 0.03% solution been?
Patient: I've been using it once a day as you instructed.
Doctor: Great! I can see increased hair growth and thickening of your eyebrow hairs. Have you experienced any treatment-associated side effects?
Patient: No, I haven't had any side effects from the treatment.
Doctor: That's excellent! After eight months, it looks like you have complete regrowth of your eyebrows. We'll continue with the daily topical treatment of bimatoprost 0.03% solution to maintain these results.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I'm really happy with the progress and the treatment.
soap:
S: The patient, a female with no significant medical history, presented with the chief complaint of eyebrow thinning, specifically noting no other areas of hair loss on her body. She reported a history of eyebrow plucking, which could be relevant to her current condition.
O: Physical examination revealed sparse and thin black hairs on the eyebrows with no signs of hair loss on the frontal hairline or temporal areas. No other abnormalities were noted during the examination. The patient has been using bimatoprost 0.03% solution daily as prescribed, with no reported side effects.
A: The primary diagnosis is idiopathic eyebrow hypotrichosis. The patient's history and clinical findings support this diagnosis, with no evidence of other dermatological or systemic diseases contributing to the hair loss. The prognosis is good, given the positive response to treatment observed during follow-up.
P: The management plan includes continued daily application of bimatoprost 0.03% solution to the affected areas to maintain hair regrowth. The patient is scheduled for periodic follow-up visits every two months to monitor progress and adherence to the treatment regimen. Education on the gradual nature of treatment response and encouragement of patient compliance have been emphasized. No referral to other specialties is needed at this time.

dialogue:
Doctor: Good morning, ma'am. I see you were admitted to the emergency department with a complaint of palpitations that started a few hours ago. Can you describe the palpitations for me?
Patient: Hi, doctor. Yeah, my heart has been beating really fast and irregularly for the past few hours. It's quite uncomfortable.
Doctor: I understand. We've done a 12-lead ECG, which suggests that you have atrial fibrillation. I also noticed in your medical history that you've been taking oral anticoagulation therapy for recurrent episodes of atrial fibrillation and topiramate for essential tremor in your arms. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. I've had these issues before, and the medications help manage them.
Doctor: After you were admitted, we administered an intravenous dose of amiodarone to help with your current symptoms. Your new 12-lead ECG is now compatible with atrial flutter, having a cycle length of 240 ms and a 4:1 atrioventricular response.
Patient: Oh, okay. What does that mean?
Doctor: Atrial flutter is a different type of abnormal heart rhythm, but it's related to atrial fibrillation. The cycle length and atrioventricular response we observed indicate that your heart rhythm has changed, but it's still not regular.
Patient: I see. So, what's the next step?
Doctor: We wanted to further evaluate the underlying heart rhythm, so we performed a two-dimensional transthoracic echocardiography (2D TTE) on you. This is an ultrasound of your heart to see how it's functioning.
Patient: And what did you find?
Doctor: We measured the transmitral flow using pulsed-wave Doppler and found a diastolic pattern with a normal atrial rhythm. This means that your heart is functioning relatively well despite the abnormal rhythm.
Patient: That's a relief. What do we do now?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your heart rhythm and adjust your medications as needed. It's important for you to keep taking your prescribed medications and follow up with your cardiologist regularly for further evaluation and management.
Patient: Alright, doctor. I appreciate your help. I'll make sure to follow up with my cardiologist and take my medications as prescribed.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you experience any worsening symptoms or have any concerns, do not hesitate to contact your healthcare team or come back to the emergency department. Take care and stay safe.
soap:
S: The patient, a female with a history of recurrent atrial fibrillation and essential tremor, presented to the emergency department with palpitations described as fast and irregular, which started a few hours prior to admission. She reports discomfort associated with these symptoms. The patient confirms ongoing treatment with oral anticoagulation therapy and topiramate.
O: Initial 12-lead ECG indicated atrial fibrillation. Post-administration of intravenous amiodarone, a follow-up 12-lead ECG showed atrial flutter with a cycle length of 240 ms and a 4:1 atrioventricular response. Two-dimensional transthoracic echocardiography (2D TTE) revealed a diastolic pattern with a normal atrial rhythm, indicating relatively good cardiac function despite the abnormal rhythm.
A: The primary diagnosis is atrial flutter, previously managed as atrial fibrillation. The patient's heart function is stable as evidenced by the 2D TTE findings, but the presence of atrial flutter necessitates ongoing monitoring and possible adjustment of her current therapeutic regimen.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's heart rhythm and adjust medications as necessary. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to her prescribed medication regimen and schedule regular follow-up visits with her cardiologist. She is also instructed to seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or new concerns arise.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you were admitted to our hospital due to ecchymosis on both lower extremities. Can you tell me more about your medical history?
Patient: Yes, three years before admission, I was diagnosed with ITP through laboratory tests, including antibodies against platelet glycoprotein IIb/IIIa and GP IV, and bone marrow aspiration. I was treated successfully with corticosteroids. I also have a history of nontuberculosis mycobacterial infection.
Doctor: I see. What treatment were you on before coming here?
Patient: I was taking prednisolone, clarithromycin, rifampicin, and ethambutol hydrochloride.
Doctor: Okay. I have your recent examination results here. Two weeks before admission, your platelet counts were normal, at 185 × 10^9/l. However, on admission, your laboratory findings showed a significant drop in platelet count, to 3.0 × 10^9/l. Your biochemical parameters and coagulation values were within the normal limit, and antibodies against Helicobacter pylori, hepatitis C virus, hepatitis B virus, and HIV were negative. Based on this, we diagnosed you with acute exacerbation of chronic ITP.
Patient: Oh, no. What will be my treatment now?
Doctor: We started you on high-dose IVIG, PSL (40 mg/day), and romiplostim (1 µg/kg). However, during the next four days, you developed respiratory failure with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of approximately 250. We performed a computed tomography (CT) on the fourth day of hospitalization, which revealed ground-glass opacities with marginal infiltration in both lung fields. This led us to diagnose you with alveolar hemorrhage. 
Patient: That's terrible. What happened next?
Doctor: As your dyspnea worsened gradually, we initiated noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV) to help you breathe. On the 11th day of hospitalization, we increased the dose of romiplostim to 10 µg/kg and administered pulsed doses of methyl-PSL (1000 mg/day for 3 days) along with a second cycle of IVIG.
Patient: Did that help?
Doctor: Yes, by the 21st day of hospitalization, your platelet count recovered, and you were discharged without any complications.
Patient: That's a relief. What's my current situation?
Doctor: Your platelet count has remained normal while being treated with 12.5 mg of prednisolone. We will continue to monitor your condition and adjust your treatment as necessary. Make sure to attend any follow-up appointments and report any new symptoms or concerns.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and will make sure to follow your instructions.
soap:
S: The patient, previously diagnosed with Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP) and treated with corticosteroids, was admitted with ecchymosis on both lower extremities. The patient reported a history of nontuberculosis mycobacterial infection and was on prednisolone, clarithromycin, rifampicin, and ethambutol hydrochloride prior to admission.
O: On admission, the patient's platelet count was significantly reduced to 3.0 × 10^9/l from a previous normal count of 185 × 10^9/l. Biochemical parameters and coagulation values were normal. Tests for Helicobacter pylori, hepatitis C and B viruses, and HIV were negative. CT imaging on the fourth day showed ground-glass opacities with marginal infiltration in both lung fields, indicative of alveolar hemorrhage. The patient developed respiratory failure with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of approximately 250.
A: The primary diagnosis is an acute exacerbation of chronic ITP, complicated by alveolar hemorrhage. The patient's history of ITP and recent exacerbation, along with the development of respiratory complications, guided the diagnosis and treatment.
P: Treatment initiated with high-dose IVIG, PSL (40 mg/day), and romiplostim (1 µg/kg), escalated to 10 µg/kg due to worsening condition. Pulsed doses of methyl-PSL (1000 mg/day for 3 days) and a second cycle of IVIG were administered. Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV) was used for respiratory support. The patient's treatment will continue with monitoring and adjustments as necessary, including maintaining a dose of prednisolone at 12.5 mg. Follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and platelet count.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've been admitted to our clinic for delivery at the 37th week of your gestation. Can you tell me a bit about your pregnancy history? 
Patient: Sure, this is my sixth pregnancy. I have two children and had three abortions. I also had one previous cesarean section delivery.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. I have your preoperative blood test results here. Your hemoglobin is 10.8 g/dL, prothrombin time (PT) is 10.5 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is 29 seconds, international normalized ratio is 2.3, and platelet count is 385x109/L.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: We also performed a transabdominal sonography and magnetic resonance imaging on you. The results show total placenta previa and myometrial invasion to the urinary bladder at the anterior wall of your uterus. 
Patient: Oh, that sounds concerning.
Doctor: Yes, it can be. You mentioned earlier that you would prefer a conservative approach rather than hysterectomy in case of massive bleeding, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: After the cesarean delivery of your baby through a Pfannenstiel incision and removal of the placenta, we detected a 5-6 cm area of tissue loss at the anterior wall of the uterus. There was also bleeding from the cervix and posterior wall of the bladder.
Patient: Oh no, what did you do?
Doctor: We applied pelvic packing on the pelvic vessels for 20 minutes and sutured the bleeding sites with 1.0 polyglactine sutures. We also placed a Sengstaken-Blakemore balloon catheter in the uterus before suturing.
Patient: And did that help?
Doctor: We filled the stomach balloon with 250 mL saline and the esophageal balloon with 400 mL saline to provide compression on the lower uterine isthmic and cervical bleeds. However, bleeding continued.
Patient: What happened next?
Doctor: Bilateral uterine and hypogastric artery ligations were planned due to the hemorrhage. During the procedure, the left external iliac artery was accidentally held and bonded as the left hypogastric artery, but we released it within a minute after distinguishing the vessels.
Patient: Oh, I see. 
Doctor: Following that, we successfully ligated the uterine and hypogastric arteries on both sides. You lost about 2000 cc of blood due to the intraoperative hemorrhage, which we measured by adding 1650 cc blood in the aspirator and counting the gauzes.
Patient: That's a lot of blood.
Doctor: Yes, it is. We gave you erythrocyte suspension (3 units preoperatively and 4 unites postoperatively) and 3 packs of fresh frozen plasma to help with the blood loss.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate all that you did to help me during the delivery.
soap:
S: The patient, a 37-week pregnant woman with a history of two live births, three abortions, and one previous cesarean section, presented for delivery. She expressed a preference for conservative management over hysterectomy in the event of massive bleeding.
O: Hemoglobin was 10.8 g/dL, prothrombin time (PT) 10.5 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 29 seconds, international normalized ratio (INR) 2.3, and platelet count 385x10^9/L. Imaging revealed total placenta previa and myometrial invasion into the urinary bladder. During cesarean delivery, a 5-6 cm area of tissue loss at the anterior wall of the uterus was noted, with bleeding from the cervix and posterior bladder wall. Pelvic packing and suturing were performed, followed by placement of a Sengstaken-Blakemore balloon catheter. Despite these measures, bleeding continued, leading to bilateral uterine and hypogastric artery ligations. The patient lost approximately 2000 cc of blood. She received 3 units of erythrocyte suspension preoperatively and 4 units postoperatively, along with 3 packs of fresh frozen plasma.
A: The patient was diagnosed with total placenta previa and myometrial invasion, complicated by significant intraoperative hemorrhage. The accidental temporary bonding of the left external iliac artery was promptly corrected. The patient's condition stabilized following the surgical interventions.
P: Continue monitoring hemoglobin levels and coagulation parameters closely. Administer iron supplements and consider additional blood transfusions if necessary. Provide postoperative care including pain management and infection prevention. Schedule follow-up appointments for wound care and psychological support considering the traumatic nature of the delivery. Educate the patient on signs of infection or complications to watch for during recovery.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I've been informed that you were referred here for the evaluation of radicular pain you've been experiencing over the posterior aspect of your right leg and numbness at the planter aspect of your right foot. Can you tell me how long you've been experiencing this discomfort?
Patient: Yeah, it's been going on for about 3 weeks now.
Doctor: I see. I also noted that you have a history of being injured by missile fragments 11 years before your admission. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Sure, I'm in the military and got injured during a mission. I've had some issues since then, but this pain is new.
Doctor: Okay. Your previous doctor suspected a probable diagnosis of S1 root radiculopathy from L5–S1 disc herniation and performed a lumbar myelography, which came back normal. However, since you still have discomfort, they referred you to our institution. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I conducted a neurological exam and found distal sciatica along the course of your S1 root, with hypoesthesia of your right sole. Upon further examination and palpation, I discovered a painful and pulsatile mass in your popliteal region. I also heard a bruit during auscultation. Based on these findings, I suspected a pseudoaneurysm and ordered a selective angiography.
Patient: Oh, what did that reveal?
Doctor: The angiography revealed a pseudoaneurysm arising from the proximal segment of your anterior tibial artery. The artery appears to be bowed due to the compressive effect of the pseudoaneurysms.
Patient: So, what does that mean?
Doctor: Considering there was a difference between the size of the aneurysm in angiography and the size of the mass during palpation, I ordered a contrasted CT scan to estimate the exact size of the aneurysm. The scan showed a large isointense mass with rim enhancement surrounding a hyperdense area. The rim is compatible with the pseudocapsule of the aneurysm. The isointense mass is an old clot, and the hyperdense area is the patent part of the aneurysm.
Patient: That sounds pretty serious. What's the next step?
Doctor: We will need to consult with a vascular specialist to discuss treatment options for the pseudoaneurysm. You may require surgical intervention. In the meantime, we will continue to monitor your condition and manage your pain.
Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor. I appreciate your thorough evaluation and explanation.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns. We'll be here to help you through this process.
soap:
S: The patient, a military personnel, reports experiencing radicular pain along the posterior aspect of the right leg and numbness on the plantar aspect of the right foot for 3 weeks. The patient has a history of injury from missile fragments 11 years ago, which has caused ongoing issues, though the current symptoms are new. Previous diagnosis by another doctor suggested S1 root radiculopathy from L5-S1 disc herniation, but lumbar myelography was normal.
O: Neurological examination revealed distal sciatica along the S1 root and hypoesthesia of the right sole. A painful, pulsatile mass was palpated in the popliteal region, with an audible bruit on auscultation. Selective angiography showed a pseudoaneurysm arising from the proximal segment of the anterior tibial artery, with the artery bowed due to the compressive effect of the pseudoaneurysms. A contrasted CT scan confirmed a large isointense mass with rim enhancement surrounding a hyperdense area, indicative of an old clot and the patent part of the aneurysm.
A: The primary diagnosis is a pseudoaneurysm of the anterior tibial artery, likely secondary to previous trauma and causing compression of nearby structures, including the S1 nerve root. This condition explains the patient's symptoms of radicular pain and numbness. Differential diagnosis initially included S1 radiculopathy secondary to disc herniation, which was ruled out by normal myelography.
P: The management plan includes referral to a vascular specialist for evaluation and potential surgical intervention for the pseudoaneurysm. Pain management will continue, and the patient's condition will be closely monitored. The patient has been advised to reach out with any further questions or concerns as we proceed with treatment planning.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you have a 10-year history of BD. Have you been receiving any treatment for it recently?
Patient: No, I haven't been treated for it in the last 2 years.
Doctor: I see. So, you've been referred to our cardiovascular surgery department with symptoms of serious aches in your left arm, edema, and apparent veins on your left anterior chest wall, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: We performed a color Doppler ultrasonography of your left upper extremity venous system, and it showed a total thrombosis of the left internal and external jugular veins and the left subclavian vein. To treat this, we ordered a single dose of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) (7500 IU/0.3 mL of bemiparin sodium) for a day, along with antibiotics and anti-inflammatory drugs. How have you been feeling since your discharge from the hospital?
Patient: Well, a month after I was discharged, I started experiencing dyspnea and coughs.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. During your physical examination, we found decreased occultation sounds in the middle and bottom fields of your left thorax. A posteroanterior direct chest radiograph also showed a consolidated region, which is in line with the auscultation findings. We performed thoracocentesis and aspirated a milky liquid from your left thorax. The biochemical analysis of the liquid demonstrated total protein of 4.3 g/dL, albumin of 2.2 g/dL, total cholesterol of 47 mg/dL, and triglycerides of 287 mg/dL.
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?
Doctor: In light of these findings, we have diagnosed you with chylothorax. We've hospitalized you and started a treatment plan that includes single doses of LMWH, 0.5 mg of colchicine, 40 mg of an oral corticosteroid (prednisolone), 2 doses of oral immunosuppressive therapy (50 mg of azathioprine), and a high-carbohydrate and low-fat dietary regimen. We've also established a left thoracic drainage system for you.
Patient: Okay, and how has that been working?
Doctor: On the seventh day of hospitalization, we noticed a progressing cheilosis flow and decided to apply a pleurodesis process with talcum powder. However, the chylothorax progression continued for the following 3 days. We then decided to inject 60 mL of venous autologous blood into your left thorax via a drainage tube, which we clamped to avoid any further complications.
Patient: So, what's the next step in my treatment?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your progress, adjust your medication and dietary regimen as needed, and perform any necessary procedures to manage your chylothorax. It's important that you follow our recommendations and keep us informed of any changes in your symptoms.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. We're here to help you through this process.
soap:
S: The patient reports a 10-year history of BD (Bipolar Disorder) without recent treatment. He was referred for serious aches in the left arm, edema, and visible veins on the left anterior chest wall. Post-discharge from initial treatment, the patient started experiencing dyspnea and coughs.
O: Color Doppler ultrasonography revealed total thrombosis of the left internal and external jugular veins and the left subclavian vein. Initial treatment included 7500 IU/0.3 mL of bemiparin sodium, antibiotics, and anti-inflammatory drugs. Physical examination showed decreased occultation sounds in the middle and bottom fields of the left thorax. Chest radiograph indicated a consolidated region in the left thorax. Thoracocentesis aspirated a milky liquid, with biochemical analysis showing total protein 4.3 g/dL, albumin 2.2 g/dL, total cholesterol 47 mg/dL, and triglycerides 287 mg/dL. Current treatment includes LMWH, 0.5 mg colchicine, 40 mg prednisolone, 50 mg azathioprine, a high-carbohydrate and low-fat diet, and a left thoracic drainage system. Pleurodesis with talcum powder was performed, followed by injection of 60 mL of autologous blood into the left thorax.
A: The patient is diagnosed with chylothorax secondary to venous thrombosis. The progression of chylothorax despite initial interventions including pleurodesis and autologous blood injection indicates a complex case requiring ongoing management.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition and adjust the medication and dietary regimen as necessary. Maintain the left thoracic drainage system and perform additional procedures to manage chylothorax as required. Emphasize the importance of compliance with the treatment plan and encourage the patient to report any changes in symptoms. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to assess progress and make necessary adjustments to the treatment plan.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I've just been informed that your 19-year-old son has been admitted to the intensive unit after a suicide attempt by hanging. I'm very sorry to hear that. Can you tell me if he was found in cardiac arrest, and if so, how long do you think it lasted?
Family Member: Yes, he was found in cardiac arrest, but we're not sure about the duration.
Doctor: I see. During the transfer to the hospital, cardiac massage was performed for 40 minutes to try and revive him. Upon arrival, we assessed his condition and found him to be in a deep coma with a Glasgow score of 3/15. That's a very low score and indicates a severe brain injury.
Family Member: Oh no... What did the tests show?
Doctor: We performed an unenhanced Brain Computed Tomography (CT) after five hours. The images demonstrated bilateral hypodensity in the basal ganglia, which can be seen as the white arrowheads. There was also hyperdensity in the cerebral arteries, which seems to be related to the underlying brain hypodensity. This is likely due to a decrease in gray-white differentiation caused by edema, or swelling, in the brain.
Family Member: What happened next?
Doctor: We continued to monitor his condition and performed another unenhanced CT after 30 hours. Unfortunately, there was progression of brain edema, causing a collapse of the sylvian fissures, basal cisterns, and cortical sulci. These are indicated by the black arrows in the images.
Family Member: And what does that mean?
Doctor: This also led to diffuse hyperdensity of all collapsed subarachnoid spaces, which became prominent and is indicated by the white arrows. This condition is called pseudo-subarachnoid hemorrhage (PSAH).
Family Member: Is there any chance of recovery?
Doctor: We conducted multiple evoked potential tests after 48 hours to assess his brain function. I'm very sorry to inform you that the tests have confirmed that he is brain dead.
Family Member: Oh no... I can't believe this is happening. What do we do now?
Doctor: I understand this is an extremely difficult time for you and your family. Our team will provide you with all the necessary support and information to help you through this process. We'll discuss the next steps and address any concerns or questions you may have.
soap:
S: The patient, a 19-year-old male, was admitted following a suicide attempt by hanging. He was found in cardiac arrest, although the duration is unclear. Upon admission, he was in a deep coma with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3/15, indicating severe brain injury.
O: Initial unenhanced Brain CT showed bilateral hypodensity in the basal ganglia and hyperdensity in the cerebral arteries, suggesting edema and decreased gray-white differentiation. A follow-up CT 30 hours later indicated progression of brain edema, collapse of sylvian fissures, basal cisterns, and cortical sulci, and diffuse hyperdensity of all collapsed subarachnoid spaces, consistent with pseudo-subarachnoid hemorrhage (PSAH). Evoked potential tests conducted after 48 hours confirmed brain death.
A: The primary diagnosis is brain death secondary to anoxic brain injury following a suicide attempt by hanging. The findings on CT and evoked potential tests support this diagnosis. Differential diagnosis would consider other causes of coma, but clinical findings and imaging are conclusive for brain death.
P: The management plan includes providing support and information to the family to help them through this process. Discussions regarding organ donation, if applicable, and end-of-life care decisions will be facilitated. No further medical interventions are indicated. Referral to counseling services for the family is recommended to aid in coping with the loss.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I see that you have a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been feeling really sick for the past 4-5 days. I've had vomiting, nausea, and a really bad headache. 
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about your headache? 
Patient: It came on suddenly, and it's really sharp and right at the front of my head. It's been so bad, like an 8 out of 10 on a pain scale. 
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Have you experienced any constipation, abdominal pain, or distension in the past few days?
Patient: Yeah, I've been constipated for 4-5 days too, but no abdominal pain or distension. 
Doctor: Alright. Have you had any visual disturbances, neck pain, neck rigidity, or fever recently? 
Patient: No, none of those symptoms. 
Doctor: Have you had any recent alcohol intake or unusual food prior to the onset of these symptoms?
Patient: No, I haven't had any alcohol or unusual food lately.
Doctor: We've checked your vitals and initially you had hypotension with a blood pressure of 68/54 mm Hg. After administering two liters of normal saline infusion, it improved to 94/55 mm Hg. Your physical exam showed dry mucosa but no focal neurological deficits were noted.
Patient: Okay, that's good to know.
Doctor: We also performed a computed tomography (CT) scan of your head, which was reported to be unremarkable with no evidence of acute intracranial pathologies.
Patient: Hmm, that's a relief.
Doctor: Your blood workup showed hyponatremia with a serum sodium level of 128 mmol/L (normal: 137-145 mmol/L) and hypokalemia with a serum potassium level of 3.2 mmol/L (normal: 3.5-5.1 mmol/L). Your serum bicarbonate was 27 mmol/L (normal: 22-30 mmol/L) and serum glucose was 171 mg/dL (normal: 74-105 mg/dL). Your blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine levels were 56 mg/dL (normal: 9-20 mg/dL) and 3.3 mg/dL (normal: 0.8-1.5 mg/dL), respectively.
Patient: Oh, I see. So, what does all of that mean?
Doctor: Based on your symptoms and test results, we've admitted you with an initial impression of acute kidney injury secondary to acute volume depletion resulting from vomiting. We have initiated aggressive hydration to help correct this issue, as well as replacing your electrolytes.
Patient: Okay, I hope that helps me feel better.
Doctor: Over the next several hours, your hypotension resolved, and there was an improvement in your condition.
Patient: That's good news. So, what's next for me, Doctor?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your vitals, electrolyte levels, and overall condition. It is essential to follow-up with any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan. 
Patient: Alright, thank you for helping me with this, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care, and we'll do everything we can to help you recover as quickly as possible.
soap:
S: Patient, with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2, presents with a 4-5 day history of vomiting, nausea, severe frontal headache rated 8/10, and constipation. No recent unusual food intake, alcohol consumption, abdominal pain, distension, visual disturbances, neck pain, neck rigidity, or fever reported.
O: Initial hypotension (68/54 mm Hg) improved to 94/55 mm Hg post two liters of normal saline infusion. Physical exam showed dry mucosa, no focal neurological deficits. CT head unremarkable. Labs: Hyponatremia (Na 128 mmol/L), hypokalemia (K 3.2 mmol/L), normal bicarbonate (27 mmol/L), elevated glucose (171 mg/dL), elevated blood urea nitrogen (56 mg/dL), and creatinine (3.3 mg/dL).
A: Primary diagnosis of acute kidney injury secondary to acute volume depletion from vomiting. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute kidney injury and electrolyte imbalances. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with appropriate management.
P: Continued aggressive hydration and electrolyte replacement. Monitoring of vitals, electrolyte levels, and renal function closely. Adjustments to treatment plan as necessary based on response and lab results. Education on the importance of hydration and managing underlying chronic conditions like hypertension and diabetes.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I have reviewed your medical history, and it seems that you've been experiencing mild low back pain for the past 3 years. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, that's correct. But in the last 20 days, the pain has worsened severely, and it's now radiating to the back of my lower limbs. I've also had a lot of difficulty walking.
Doctor: I see. When I examined your lumbar spine and sacroiliac joints, I found that the palpation was painful, which is a positive Patrick's test. We also did some laboratory analysis, and your inflammatory markers, such as reactive C protein, were found to be normal. Are you aware of any other health issues or habits that could be related to your condition?
Patient: Well, I am a heavy smoker, but I don't have any other comorbidities.
Doctor: Thank you for that information. We performed an MRI, which demonstrated an infiltrative mass affecting the vertebral body and pedicles of your L4 vertebra. There was also heterogeneous enhancement after the contrast administration. The tumor has extended into the distal third of your inferior vena cava and the left iliopsoas muscle.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We also performed a CT scan, which showed a lytic lesion with indistinct borders in the vertebral body of your fourth lumbar vertebra (L4). There was a soft tissue component that dislocated the aorta and the inferior vena cava. Additionally, there was a typical "ring-and-arc" chondroid matrix mineralization in the L4 vertebral body.
Patient: What does this all mean, doc?
Doctor: We decided to perform a needle transpedicular biopsy of the vertebral lesion to better understand your condition. The biopsy revealed a malignant infiltrative bone neoplasm with chondroid differentiation and several areas of necrosis.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: Three weeks after the needle biopsy, we performed a posterior lumbar approach, installing pedicle screws at L3 and L5, and removed the posterior elements. We also dissected the anterior large vessels from the spine and performed an "en bloc" resection of L4. We reconstructed your lumbar spine with a titanium cage and an anterolateral plate.
Patient: And what were the results of that?
Doctor: The histopathological examination of the resected L4 vertebral body revealed an infiltrative malignant biphasic neoplasia composed of ample ill-defined areas.
Patient: What does this mean for my future treatment?
Doctor: We will need to discuss further treatment options, including potential chemotherapy and radiation therapy, to target and manage the malignant neoplasm. It is crucial that you follow up with your medical team regularly to monitor your progress and adjust treatment as necessary.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and guidance throughout this process.
soap:
S: The patient reports a history of mild low back pain for the past 3 years, which has severely worsened in the last 20 days, now radiating to the back of the lower limbs and causing difficulty walking. The patient is a heavy smoker with no other reported comorbidities.
O: Physical examination revealed pain on palpation of the lumbar spine and sacroiliac joints, with a positive Patrick's test. Laboratory analysis showed normal inflammatory markers, including reactive C protein. MRI and CT scans identified an infiltrative mass in the L4 vertebral body, extending into the inferior vena cava and left iliopsoas muscle, with lytic lesions and "ring-and-arc" chondroid matrix mineralization. A needle transpedicular biopsy indicated a malignant infiltrative bone neoplasm with chondroid differentiation. Post-surgical histopathology confirmed infiltrative malignant biphasic neoplasia.
A: The primary diagnosis is a malignant infiltrative bone neoplasm with chondroid differentiation at the L4 vertebra. Differential diagnoses could include other types of primary spinal tumors or metastatic disease. The prognosis depends on the response to further oncological treatments and the extent of disease spread.
P: The patient underwent surgical resection of the L4 vertebra and spinal reconstruction. The next steps include discussing additional treatments such as chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Regular follow-ups with the oncology team are essential to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Smoking cessation should be strongly advised to support overall health and treatment efficacy.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, we have a report of a 6-year-old boy who was admitted to the emergency unit due to severe hypothermia and unconsciousness. Can you tell me if he had any medical history that we should be aware of?
Patient's Parent: No, his medical history was not contributive.
Doctor: Okay. It seems that he was transferred here by a mobile emergency medical service. Upon admission, we assessed his vital parameters and clinical examination. His Glasgow Coma Scale score was 5/15 with fixed dilated pupils, a core rectal temperature of 27.2°C, and SpO2 of 98% with supplemental oxygen. He also had irregular respiration, sinus bradycardia at 60 bpm, normal blood pressure of 98/72 mmHg with a mean blood pressure of 79 mmHg, and a prolonged capillary refilling time of 4 seconds. Additionally, there was muscle rigidity and obvious hypotrophy. 
Patient's Parent: Oh my, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is quite concerning. During admission, we performed rapid-sequence intubation and non-invasive rewarming. We also administered fluid replacement boluses of normal saline to help stabilize him. 
Patient's Parent: Okay, thank you for doing that. How are his blood test results?
Doctor: His blood gas and first laboratory assessments within 8 hours of admission showed a compensated metabolic acidosis, hyperlactatemia with a lactatemia level of 5.5 mmol/L (normal is less than 2 mmol/L), and hyperglycemia at 340 mg/dL (normal range is 70-100 mg/dL). He also has mild thrombocytopenia with a count of 124,000/µL (normal range is 150,000-440,000/µL).
Patient's Parent: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What about his other test results?
Doctor: There were elevated biomarkers of myocardial and muscular damage such as serum CK-MB, which was up to 2,262 UI/L (normal is less than 190 UI/L), myoglobin at 1,978 ng/mL (normal is less than 72 ng/mL), and troponin at 684 ng/L (normal is less than 14.0 ng/L). Additionally, there was a mild alteration of coagulation screening with PT at 51% (normal is more than 70%) and INR at 1.46 (normal range is 0.95-1.31). He also has hypertransaminasemia with AST up to 2,700 UI/L (normal is less than 40 UI/L) and ALT up to 2,000 UI/L (normal is less than 41 UI/L). Fortunately, his renal and pancreatic functions are normal.
Patient's Parent: I see. What are the next steps for his treatment and recovery?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor his vital signs and blood test results closely. He may require further interventions and treatments depending on his progress. It's important to keep a close eye on his condition and follow up with any necessary medical care.
Patient's Parent: Thank you, Doctor. We appreciate all your efforts in treating our son. Please keep us updated on his condition.
soap:
S: A 6-year-old boy was admitted with severe hypothermia and unconsciousness. The patient's parent reported no significant medical history. The chief complaints at admission were unconsciousness, hypothermia, and muscle rigidity.
O: On examination, the patient had a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 5/15, fixed dilated pupils, core rectal temperature of 27.2°C, SpO2 of 98% on supplemental oxygen, irregular respiration, and sinus bradycardia at 60 bpm. Blood pressure was 98/72 mmHg with a mean of 79 mmHg, and capillary refill time was prolonged at 4 seconds. Laboratory findings included compensated metabolic acidosis, hyperlactatemia (5.5 mmol/L), hyperglycemia (340 mg/dL), mild thrombocytopenia (platelet count 124,000/µL), elevated CK-MB (2,262 UI/L), myoglobin (1,978 ng/mL), troponin (684 ng/L), hypertransaminasemia (AST 2,700 UI/L, ALT 2,000 UI/L), and mild coagulation alteration (PT 51%, INR 1.46). Renal and pancreatic functions were normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe hypothermia with complications including metabolic acidosis, hyperlactatemia, hyperglycemia, thrombocytopenia, myocardial and muscular damage, and liver dysfunction. Differential diagnoses could include underlying infectious or metabolic disorders contributing to the presentation.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of vital signs and laboratory values, maintaining rewarming protocols, fluid replacement therapy, and supportive care for organ dysfunction. Further interventions will be based on the patient's evolving clinical status. Regular updates will be provided to the parents to keep them informed of their child's condition and progress.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello there, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having some discomfort in my groin area lately.
Doctor: Alright, let me start by conducting a physical examination to better understand the situation. Is that okay with you?
Patient: Yes, sure.
Doctor: (After examining) Based on the physical examination, your phenotype seems like that of a 3-year-old boy with a normal size penis. I found a palpable testis in your left groin and a nonpalpable undescended testis on the right side.
Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that one of your testes hasn't descended to its proper location in the scrotum. We may need to do further tests like an MRI to get a clearer picture of what's going on.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
(After the MRI)
Doctor: The MRI results show that your left testis is located in the left hemiscrotum, measuring 1.3 × 0.6 cm. It's associated with a mild hydrocele. Another testis, measuring 1.2 × 0.6 cm, was found on the ipsilateral side within the left inguinal canal.
Patient: What does that mean for me?
Doctor: This means that both of your testes are on the same side, one above the other, which is unusual. We'll need to perform an exploration of the left groin to determine the cause of this and to plan the necessary treatment.
Patient: Alright, let's do that then.
(After the exploration)
Doctor: During the exploration, we found the presence of both testes within the same side. Each testis has separate vasa deferentia and testicular vessels, but they share a common cremasteric muscle and tunical covering. 
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: The next step is to perform a herniotomy. After the procedure, the ectopic testis will be fixed transseptally to the right hemiscrotum. This should help alleviate your discomfort and allow your testes to function properly.
Patient: Will there be any long-term effects from the herniotomy?
Doctor: The procedure is generally safe and effective, and most patients recover well. We'll monitor your progress and provide any necessary follow-up care.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap:
S: The patient, a 3-year-old boy, reports discomfort in the groin area. He has no other symptoms mentioned.
O: Physical examination revealed a palpable testis in the left groin and a nonpalpable undescended testis on the right side. MRI findings confirmed the left testis in the left hemiscrotum, measuring 1.3 × 0.6 cm with a mild hydrocele, and another testis measuring 1.2 × 0.6 cm in the left inguinal canal. Surgical exploration showed both testes on the same side, each with separate vasa deferentia and testicular vessels, sharing a common cremasteric muscle and tunical covering.
A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral cryptorchidism with ectopic testis. The presence of both testes on the same side with shared anatomical features is unusual and requires surgical intervention to prevent complications such as infertility and increased risk of testicular cancer.
P: The management plan includes performing a herniotomy to reposition the ectopic testis transseptally to the right hemiscrotum. Post-operative care will involve monitoring for recovery and effectiveness of the procedure, with follow-up visits to assess testicular function and position. Education will be provided to the parents about the importance of follow-up and potential long-term effects.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me how you're feeling right now and what symptoms you've experienced?
Patient: Yeah, I developed nausea, vomiting, headache, chest tightness, and shortness of breath while working outdoors for 2 hours in a southern city in China. It was a hot afternoon, the temperature was 35°C. I'm originally from the north part of China, you know.
Doctor: I see. What happened after you experienced these symptoms?
Patient: After around 15 hours, I went into a coma and was then transferred to the emergency department of the hospital.
Doctor: We've done some tests since you arrived. Upon arrival, your temperature was 40.2 °C, blood pressure was 75/40 mmHg, and pulse rate was 100 beats/min. Your blood oxygen saturation under balloon-assisted ventilation was 95%. 
Patient: Oh, that sounds bad.
Doctor: Yes, we also performed some laboratory tests, which indicated rhabdomyolysis syndrome, acute kidney injury, hepatic dysfunction, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis. Your serum D-dimer level was elevated at 1022 μg/L, while the normal range is 0–232 μg/L. Based on these findings, we diagnosed you with Heatstroke (HS).
Patient: Oh no! So, what are you doing to treat me?
Doctor: We've been treating you with a cooling blanket and plasma exchange, along with assisted ventilation to help stabilize your condition.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: On the 3rd day of your admission, we performed brain CT scans, which showed symmetrical low-density lesions in the bilateral basal ganglia. On the 7th day, your state of consciousness improved, but you mentioned having blurred vision, right?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: We did an eye examination, and the results were normal. To get a better understanding of your brain, we performed a brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) 8 days after admission.
Patient: What did the MRI show?
Doctor: The cerebral MRI revealed a slight hyperintensity in the bilateral putamen on the diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) sequence and bilateral symmetrical hypointensity in the middle of the putamen and hyperintensity around the hypointensity on the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC), fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR), and T2-weighted imaging (T2WI) sequences.
Patient: I don't really understand all that. What does it mean for me?
Doctor: These MRI findings suggest that there are some changes in your brain due to the heatstroke. We will continue to monitor your condition closely and provide appropriate treatment as needed. It's important to follow up with us regularly to ensure your recovery.
Patient: Okay, I understand. Thanks for explaining everything to me, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out to us. We're here to help you through your recovery.
soap:
S: The patient, a male from northern China, reported experiencing nausea, vomiting, headache, chest tightness, and shortness of breath after working outdoors for 2 hours in a hot environment (35°C) in southern China. Symptoms escalated to a coma approximately 15 hours later, prompting emergency hospitalization.
O: Upon hospital admission, the patient's vital signs were critical with a temperature of 40.2°C, blood pressure at 75/40 mmHg, and pulse rate at 100 beats/min. Blood oxygen saturation was maintained at 95% with balloon-assisted ventilation. Laboratory tests indicated rhabdomyolysis syndrome, acute kidney injury, hepatic dysfunction, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis. Serum D-dimer was significantly elevated at 1022 μg/L (normal range 0–232 μg/L). Brain CT and MRI findings showed symmetrical low-density lesions in the bilateral basal ganglia and slight hyperintensity in the bilateral putamen, among other abnormalities.
A: The primary diagnosis is Heatstroke (HS), complicated by multi-organ dysfunction including rhabdomyolysis, acute kidney injury, and hepatic dysfunction. The brain imaging findings suggest potential neurological damage secondary to HS. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of altered mental status and multi-organ failure, but clinical presentation and context strongly support HS.
P: The patient is being managed with a cooling blanket, plasma exchange, and assisted ventilation. Continuous monitoring of vital signs, organ functions, and neurological status is essential. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to assess recovery and manage any long-term complications. Patient education on recognizing and preventing heatstroke, especially considering his non-acclimatization to southern climates, is crucial. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of neurological symptoms is recommended.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you've been referred to our hospital due to an increase in size of a tumor in your vulva. Can you tell me when you first noticed this mass?
Patient: Hi, yes. The mass was first pointed out to me during my delivery one year ago.
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any symptoms related to this mass?
Patient: No, I haven't had any apparent symptoms.
Doctor: Okay. We did a Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of your pelvis, which showed a well-circumscribed mass in the vulva. To address this issue, you underwent a resection of the tumor, and we performed a histological examination on it. I'm glad to report there's been no apparent evidence of recurrence one year after the resection.
Patient: That's good to hear. What did the examination show?
Doctor: Grossly, the tumor mass was located in the subcutis and measured 73×29 mm. There was no fibrous capsule, but the tumor was well circumscribed. The cut surface showed a yellowish-white mass with gelatinous change. Importantly, no hemorrhage or necrosis was observed.
Patient: Hmm, okay. And what about the histopathological examination?
Doctor: On histopathological examination, the boundary between the tumor and adjacent tissue was clear. The tumor cells were short and spindle-shaped without prominent atypia. No necrosis or mitoses were identified. The stroma was edematous and myxoid, with fine collagen as well as dense collagen detected in some regions.
Patient: What about the blood vessels in the area?
Doctor: The vast majority of blood vessels were small-sized with thin walls. Some medium-sized blood vessels were also identified within the lesion. There was no specific distribution pattern of the vascularity.
Patient: Did you perform any immunohistochemical studies?
Doctor: Yes, we conducted immunohistochemical studies using the primary antibodies listed in the report. On immunohistochemical analysis, most tumor cells showed positivity for vimentin, ER, PgR, and desmin. Some tumor cells were positive for alpha-SMA and CD34. The tumor cells were uniformly negative for S100 protein.
Patient: What about the Ki-67 labeling index?
Doctor: The Ki-67 labeling index was less than 2%, which is a good sign.
Patient: That's a relief. What are the follow-up requirements for my case?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your condition through regular checkups and imaging studies to ensure there's no recurrence of the tumor. Make sure to report any new symptoms or changes in your health.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate all the information and care.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out. Take care.
soap:
S: The patient, a female who noticed a mass in her vulva first pointed out during delivery one year ago, reports no symptoms associated with the mass.
O: MRI of the pelvis revealed a well-circumscribed mass in the vulva. Resection of the tumor was performed, and histological examination showed a subcutaneous tumor measuring 73×29 mm, with a yellowish-white, gelatinous cut surface, no fibrous capsule, hemorrhage, or necrosis. Histopathological analysis indicated short, spindle-shaped tumor cells without prominent atypia or mitoses, and an edematous, myxoid stroma with varying collagen density. Immunohistochemical studies showed positivity for vimentin, ER, PgR, desmin, alpha-SMA, and CD34, with negativity for S100 protein. The Ki-67 labeling index was less than 2%.
A: The patient was diagnosed with a benign spindle cell tumor of the vulva, likely a myxoid type based on histopathology and immunohistochemistry. The low Ki-67 index and absence of atypia or mitoses suggest a low risk of malignancy and recurrence.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-up visits and imaging studies to monitor for any recurrence of the tumor. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in health immediately. Further consultations with oncology may be considered if any changes are detected during follow-up.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 64-year-old man who has been referred to our institution due to cholelithiasis. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: During our examination, we incidentally found an aortic arch anomaly, KD with an ARSA (orifice diameter of 30 mm) and a distal arch aneurysm (diameter of 55 mm) (Fig.). It seems difficult to expose and directly manipulate the orifice of the ARSA. 
Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean for my treatment?
Doctor: In our institution, we routinely perform extra-anatomical subclavian artery bypass in TAR to simplify the surgical technique. We've decided to proceed with a hybrid TAR with bilateral extra-anatomical axillary artery bypass (adding extra-anatomical right axillary artery bypass) to avoid a deep and difficult end-to-end anastomosis of the ARSA.
Patient: Hmm, okay. What does the procedure involve?
Doctor: First, we'll connect two pieces of branch grafts (9 mm) to both your left and right axillary arteries, which will be connected to a selective cerebral perfusion (SCP) circuit. Then, we'll perform a median sternotomy.
Patient: Median sternotomy? What's that?
Doctor: It's a surgical procedure where we'll make an incision down the middle of your chest to access your heart and lungs. The ARSA is deeply located at just the right side of the main bronchus. We'll then initiate cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) via the ascending aorta and the superior and inferior venae cavae. A left ventricle vent will be inserted from the right superior pulmonary vein during systemic cooling.
Patient: So, what happens after that?
Doctor: We'll clamp the ascending aorta and achieve cardiac arrest with an antegrade cardioplegic solution. Then, the proximal anastomosis will be performed using a 4–0 prolene. When the temperature reaches 28°C, we'll start a hypothermic circulatory arrest with retrograde cerebral perfusion (RCP) to protect your brain and flush out atheromatous debris from the arch vessels.
Patient: That sounds intense. What about the aneurysm and the ARSA?
Doctor: Inside the aorta, we'll find many red-colored thrombi in the orifice of the ARSA. We'll ligate the ARSA just at the right side of the main bronchus and the left subclavian artery at the region of origin.
Patient: I see. And after the surgery?
Doctor: We'll closely monitor your recovery and provide you with any necessary follow-up care. It's a complex procedure, but our team is well-equipped and experienced to handle it.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything to me. I feel more informed and confident in the plan now.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any more questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.
soap:
S: The patient is a 64-year-old male presenting with cholelithiasis and incidentally discovered aortic arch anomaly, specifically Kommerell's diverticulum (KD) with an aberrant right subclavian artery (ARSA) and a distal arch aneurysm. He expresses understanding and concern about the planned procedures.
O: Examination revealed an ARSA with an orifice diameter of 30 mm and a distal arch aneurysm with a diameter of 55 mm. The patient is scheduled for a hybrid total arch replacement (TAR) with bilateral extra-anatomical axillary artery bypass. The procedure involves connecting branch grafts to both axillary arteries, median sternotomy, cardiopulmonary bypass, and hypothermic circulatory arrest with retrograde cerebral perfusion.
A: Primary diagnosis is aortic arch anomaly with ARSA and distal arch aneurysm. The complexity of the ARSA's location and the presence of the aneurysm necessitate a hybrid TAR with extra-anatomical bypass and specific surgical techniques to manage the risks associated with these anomalies.
P: The management plan includes performing a hybrid TAR with bilateral extra-anatomical axillary artery bypass. Surgical steps include median sternotomy, cardiopulmonary bypass, and hypothermic circulatory arrest. Postoperative care will involve close monitoring and follow-up to manage recovery. The patient has been informed about the procedure details and expressed confidence in the treatment plan.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, what brings you to the ophthalmologic out-patient department today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've been experiencing mild horizontal diplopia in the left direction for about 3 days now, and then a headache started 17 days later.
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any nasal obstruction, epistaxis, nasal discharge, pain, hyposmia, or nasal swelling?
Patient: No, none of those symptoms.
Doctor: And have you had a history of fever, weight loss, or nocturnal sweating? Any history of diabetes, hypertension, or any neurological disease?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those either.
Doctor: Alright, let's proceed with a physical examination. Your cardiopulmonary examination is normal, and I don't observe any lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly. Now, let me perform a neuroophthalmologic examination. Your visual acuity, fields, and fundi appear normal. Your pupils are equal and reactive to light and near stimuli. There is no ptosis, but I do notice a limitation of movement in your left eye when you gaze to the left side. The function of the remaining cranial nerves is normal. There are no sensory or motor deficits in your upper and lower extremities, and all tendon reflexes are normal. It seems you have isolated left abducens nerve palsy.
Patient: Oh, I see. What's the next step?
Doctor: We'll need to conduct a computed tomography (CT) scan to get a better understanding of the issue. The CT scan revealed soft-tissue density neoplasms filling your sphenoidal sinus. We also performed a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan with gadolinium injection, which showed a homogeneous mass lesion measuring 2.8cm x 2.3cm x 2.9cm occupying the sphenoidal sinus and invading and destroying the clivus.
Patient: That doesn't sound good. What does it mean?
Doctor: We performed a rhinoendoscopy and found a mass in your sphenoidal sinus. We biopsied it, and the histological examination revealed a malignant lymphoma. The immunohistochemical staining of the tumor tissues showed CD3+, CD56+, Ki67>80%, LCA+, CD38+, and CD20−. The lymphoma cells were positive for EBER in situ hybridization. The pathological diagnosis is extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma, nasal type (ENKL).
Patient: Oh, no. What now?
Doctor: Your plasma EBV PCR yielded 1.18 x 106 copies/ml. Ten days later, you presented with B symptoms such as fever and night sweats. We checked the enlarged lymph nodes in your neck, bilateral subclavian, alar, and inguinal areas. A contrast-enhanced CT showed renal metastases.
Patient: This is a lot to take in. What's the plan for treatment?
Doctor: We understand this is a difficult situation. Your healthcare team will discuss your treatment options and develop a plan tailored to your needs. We'll be here to support you and your family throughout the process.
soap:
S: Patient reports experiencing mild horizontal diplopia predominantly in the left direction for the past 3 days, accompanied by a headache that started 17 days later. Denies any nasal symptoms such as obstruction, epistaxis, discharge, pain, hyposmia, or swelling. Also denies fever, weight loss, nocturnal sweating, and any history of diabetes, hypertension, or neurological diseases.
O: Cardiopulmonary examination normal. No lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly noted. Neuroophthalmologic examination shows normal visual acuity, fields, and fundi. Pupils are equal and reactive to light and near stimuli. No ptosis observed, but there is a limitation of movement in the left eye on lateral gaze, indicating isolated left abducens nerve palsy. Remaining cranial nerves function normally. No sensory or motor deficits in extremities, and all tendon reflexes are normal. CT scan revealed soft-tissue density neoplasms in the sphenoidal sinus. MRI with gadolinium showed a homogeneous mass lesion (2.8cm x 2.3cm x 2.9cm) in the sphenoidal sinus, invading the clivus. Histological examination of biopsied mass confirmed malignant lymphoma with immunohistochemical staining positive for CD3+, CD56+, Ki67>80%, LCA+, CD38+, CD20−, and EBER. Plasma EBV PCR yielded 1.18 x 10^6 copies/ml. Contrast-enhanced CT showed renal metastases.
A: Primary diagnosis is extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma, nasal type (ENKL), with complications including renal metastases and isolated left abducens nerve palsy. Differential diagnosis initially considered included other causes of diplopia and headache, but imaging and biopsy confirmed ENKL.
P: Plan to discuss treatment options with the healthcare team, focusing on tailored chemotherapy and possibly radiation therapy considering the aggressive nature of ENKL and presence of metastases. Patient education regarding the diagnosis, treatment options, and potential outcomes is crucial. Referral to oncology for specialized care and possible enrollment in clinical trials. Supportive care for symptoms and psychological support for the patient and family are recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor treatment response and manage any side effects.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you are a 56-year-old male patient diagnosed with pancreatic adenocarcinoma in March 2014, along with multinodular hepatic metastasis. How have you been feeling lately?
Patient: Honestly, it's been tough. I've been feeling weak and tired most of the time.
Doctor: I understand. I see that you first went through chemotherapy with FOLFIRINOX for four months, but it was discontinued due to systemic toxicity. How did you feel during that treatment?
Patient: It was really rough for me, felt sick all the time.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. After the FOLFIRINOX, you were then switched to chemotherapy with gemcitabine for another four months. How was your experience with that treatment?
Patient: It was a bit better than the FOLFIRINOX, but still not great.
Doctor: According to your records, after the gemcitabine treatment, you presented partial response of the pancreatic tumor, but there was progression of hepatic lesions and worsening of tumor markers, with CA19.9 increasing from 2,100 to 18,000 U/mL. An abdominal MRI after the second-line systemic chemotherapy showed growth of secondary hepatic lesions in segments II, IVa, VII, and VI, despite the chemotherapeutic management. In an Oncology multidisciplinary meeting, it was decided to perform SIRT. Have you noticed any changes in how you feel since the SIRT?
Patient: I feel somewhat better after the SIRT, but still not great.
Doctor: I see. Well, the good news is that three months after the SIRT, your MRI showed virtually complete necrosis of the lesions that were observed in the previous MRI. Moreover, there were necrotic areas not showing the previous lesions. These findings may correspond to necrosis of recent secondary lesions or from the hepatic parenchyma. There's also a wedge-shaped hyperenhancement area that stands out around the lesion in segment VII.
Patient: So, does that mean my condition is improving?
Doctor: It appears that the SIRT has been effective in treating some of the hepatic lesions. However, we will need to continue monitoring your progress and adjust your treatment plan as necessary.
Patient: What's the next step for me, doctor?
Doctor: We will schedule follow-up appointments and imaging studies to observe the status of your hepatic lesions and pancreatic tumor. Depending on the results, we may need to consider additional treatments or modifications to your current plan.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will do our best to help you manage your condition. If you have any concerns or further questions, please don't hesitate to ask.
soap:
S: The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of pancreatic adenocarcinoma diagnosed in March 2014 and multinodular hepatic metastasis. He reports feeling weak and tired most of the time. He experienced systemic toxicity with FOLFIRINOX and felt sick during the treatment. The patient felt slightly better with gemcitabine but still not great. He reports some improvement after SIRT but still feels not great.
O: Initial chemotherapy with FOLFIRINOX was discontinued due to toxicity. The patient was then treated with gemcitabine, showing partial response in the pancreatic tumor but progression in hepatic lesions and worsening tumor markers (CA19.9 increased from 2,100 to 18,000 U/mL). Post-second-line chemotherapy, abdominal MRI revealed growth of secondary hepatic lesions in segments II, IVa, VII, and VI. Post-SIRT, MRI showed virtually complete necrosis of these lesions and additional necrotic areas, suggesting effectiveness of SIRT. A wedge-shaped hyperenhancement area was noted around the lesion in segment VII.
A: The primary diagnosis is pancreatic adenocarcinoma with hepatic metastasis. The patient has undergone multiple lines of chemotherapy with partial response and significant side effects. Recent SIRT treatment shows promising results with significant necrosis of hepatic lesions. Continuous monitoring is necessary to assess the progression of the disease and effectiveness of the treatment.
P: The plan includes scheduling follow-up appointments and imaging studies to monitor the status of hepatic lesions and pancreatic tumor. Depending on the outcomes, adjustments to the treatment plan may be necessary. The patient will be informed about potential additional treatments based on the progression and response to the current treatment. Continuous support and information will be provided to address any concerns or questions from the patient.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I understand you're an independent 48-year-old female who has presented here today with a 3-week history of slurred speech, unsteadiness, and fatigue. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Are you currently taking any medications?
Patient: I only take occasional iron supplements, but no regular medications.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: I've had iron deficiency anaemia and a melanoma that was removed 13 years ago.
Doctor: Thank you for that information. Is there anything else I should know about your medical history?
Patient: Well, a year prior to this presentation, I had a 4-week admission where I experienced lingering depressive and anxiety symptoms after a presumed viral infection 6 months earlier. I had lethargy, intermittent headaches, nausea, diarrhoea, and unintentional weight loss of 16 Kg over a 6-month period.
Doctor: And what was the outcome of that admission?
Patient: Following a biochemical assessment, endoscopy, colonoscopy, and a CT abdomen, I was diagnosed with an episode of major depression and started on an antidepressant.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. During your clinical examination today, we noticed that you demonstrated ataxia, as you were unable to walk heel-to-toe, had a negative Romberg's test, and showed subtle dysarthria. We didn't find any other focal neurology during the neurologic examination, and your cardiorespiratory examinations were unremarkable.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We arranged a CT brain for you, and it identified multifocal haemorrhagic sites in the right cerebellar and both cerebral hemispheres. The largest was a 3-cm right cerebellar lobar bleed. The report suggests differential diagnoses of haemorrhagic metastases, possibly recurrent melanoma, or an atypical presentation of amyloid angiopathy.
Patient: That sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it does require further investigation. We have started you on dexamethasone and referred you to the neurosurgical department. They will perform a staging CT chest/abdomen and pre-operative stealth brain MRI to further assess the right cerebellar lesion and obtain a histological diagnosis.
Patient: What did the MRI show?
Doctor: The MRI confirmed multiple supra- and infratentorial lesions. Haemosiderin staining was seen in multiple sulci at the vertex, which is in keeping with a low volume of subarachnoid blood. A 4 mm posterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysm was also detected.
Patient: And what about the CT chest?
Doctor: The CT chest identified a mass in the left atrium, which is concerning for an atrial myxoma. We will continue to investigate and determine the best course of action for your treatment.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap:
S: 48-year-old female presents with a 3-week history of slurred speech, unsteadiness, and fatigue. She reports occasional use of iron supplements, a past medical history of iron deficiency anemia, melanoma excision 13 years ago, and a major depressive episode following a viral infection a year ago. She also experienced significant weight loss, lethargy, headaches, nausea, and diarrhea during that time.
O: Clinical examination revealed ataxia, negative Romberg's test, and subtle dysarthria. Neurologic and cardiorespiratory examinations were otherwise unremarkable. CT brain showed multifocal haemorrhagic sites in the right cerebellar and both cerebral hemispheres, with a 3-cm right cerebellar lobar bleed. MRI confirmed multiple supra- and infratentorial lesions and a 4 mm posterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysm. CT chest identified a mass in the left atrium. 
A: Primary diagnosis is suspected haemorrhagic metastases with differential diagnoses including recurrent melanoma and atypical amyloid angiopathy. The presence of a left atrial mass raises concern for atrial myxoma. The neurological and cardiovascular findings necessitate further investigation and management.
P: Initiated dexamethasone and referred to neurosurgery for further assessment including staging CT chest/abdomen and pre-operative stealth brain MRI. Plans include obtaining a histological diagnosis and managing the cardiovascular findings. Further consultations with oncology and cardiology are anticipated to address the complex interplay of neurological and cardiovascular issues.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. I'm here to discuss your case. We have a report of a 69-year-old Sri Lankan Tamil man who presented to the toxicology unit following a wasp sting. Can you tell me what happened?
Patient: Yes, doctor. I was stung by three wasps in the evening. After that, I started having slurred speech, my mouth deviated to the left side, and I felt weakness on the right side of my body.
Doctor: I see. Did you have any local reaction at the sites of the wasp sting or any anaphylaxis?
Patient: There was a mild local reaction, but no anaphylaxis.
Doctor: Good to know. Were you experiencing any other chronic medical illnesses before this event?
Patient: No, doctor. I was apparently well before this.
Doctor: On admission to the toxicology unit, you were conscious and rational. You were neither pale nor plethoric. Your pulse was 80 beats per minute and your blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg. The clinical examination showed no cardiac murmurs or carotid bruits. You had expressive aphasia, right-side upper motor neuron-type facial nerve palsy, with grade four weakness on the right side of your body. We also checked your random blood sugar on admission, and it was 121 mg/dL.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: We performed magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of your brain, which revealed an acute infarction in the left posterior frontal white matter. This is compatible with your clinical presentation. Your complete blood count showed a hemoglobin of 13.6 g/dL and a platelet count of 350 × 109/L. Your clotting profile was within normal limits.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: We also conducted an electrocardiogram (ECG) which showed a sinus rhythm, and a two-dimensional echocardiogram indicated normal results with good left ventricular systolic function. Your carotid duplex showed anatomically normal carotid arteries. Your fasting blood sugar was 4 mmol/L.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: Your total cholesterol was 148 mg/dL, and your low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol was 90 mg/dL. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 11 mm in the first hour. Your renal functions were normal.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: We have started you on aspirin and atorvastatin as part of your treatment plan. Rehabilitation has been arranged, including physiotherapy and speech therapy.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I hope these therapies will help me recover.
Doctor: Yes, they should help with your recovery process. We also visited your place of residence to check for any potential hazards and to ensure proper care.
Patient: I appreciate that, doctor. Thank you for all your help.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will continue to monitor your progress and adjust your treatment plan as needed. If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to reach out to us.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I will do that.
soap:
S: A 69-year-old Sri Lankan Tamil man reports being stung by three wasps, followed by slurred speech, deviation of the mouth to the left, and right-sided body weakness. He denies any history of chronic medical illnesses and anaphylaxis following the sting.
O: On examination, the patient was conscious, rational, with a pulse of 80 bpm and blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. Clinical findings included expressive aphasia, right-side upper motor neuron-type facial nerve palsy, and grade four right-sided weakness. MRI of the brain showed an acute infarction in the left posterior frontal white matter. Lab results: Hemoglobin 13.6 g/dL, Platelets 350 × 10^9/L, Random blood sugar 121 mg/dL, Fasting blood sugar 4 mmol/L, Total cholesterol 148 mg/dL, LDL cholesterol 90 mg/dL, ESR 11 mm/hr. ECG and echocardiogram were normal, and carotid duplex showed normal arteries.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute ischemic stroke, likely precipitated by the wasp sting. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute neurological deficits, but clinical findings and imaging confirm stroke.
P: Initiated treatment with aspirin and atorvastatin. Rehabilitation includes physiotherapy and speech therapy. The patient's living environment has been assessed for safety. Ongoing monitoring and adjustments to the treatment plan will be made as necessary, with encouragement for the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns.

dialogue:
