Patient: Hi doctor, I just came to the emergency department because I've been experiencing some red and painful areas on my legs for the past five days. They're also quite swollen.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me when this issue started?
Patient: It began one day after I received my first dose of the Pfizer vaccine.
Doctor: Did you have any issues with vaccinations during your childhood?
Patient: No, I had all my vaccinations as a child without any complications.
Doctor: Have you had any recent infections like COVID-19, sore throat, or diarrhea?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those infections.
Doctor: Have you ever experienced similar skin lesions or any systemic diseases before?
Patient: No, this is the first time I've had any skin issues.
Doctor: Did you use any topical or systemic medication recently?
Patient: No, I haven't used any medication.
Doctor: Do you have any family history of tuberculosis or have you been in contact with any sick patients recently?
Patient: No, there's no family history of tuberculosis and I haven't been in contact with any sick patients.
Doctor: Let me examine your skin. [Examines patient] I see multiple tender and erythematous nodules on both of your legs. Based on your history, examination, and laboratory investigation, it appears that this could be vaccine-related erythema nodosum. However, we must also consider the possibility of an Arthus-like phenomenon that can mimic erythema nodosum lesions.
Patient: Oh, I see. What can be done to relieve my symptoms?
Doctor: I'll prescribe you oral ibuprofen 600 mg to be taken four times daily. This should help relieve your symptoms.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
[Three days later]
Patient: Hi doctor, I just wanted to let you know that since starting the treatment, my symptoms have improved and the nodules started to flatten.
Doctor: That's great to hear. Please come back for a follow-up examination in two weeks.
[Two weeks later]
Patient: Hi doctor, I'm happy to report that my symptoms have completely resolved.
Doctor: That's excellent news! I'm glad that the treatment worked and your condition has improved. If you have any further issues or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out.
soap:
S: Patient, a recent recipient of the Pfizer vaccine, reports red, painful, and swollen areas on the legs starting one day post-vaccination. Denies previous similar issues, recent infections, or use of medications. No family history of tuberculosis or recent contact with sick patients.
O: Examination reveals multiple tender and erythematous nodules on both legs. No other systemic signs noted. Vital signs and laboratory investigations were within normal limits, not detailed in the transcript.
A: Primary diagnosis of vaccine-related erythema nodosum considered, with differential diagnosis of an Arthus-like phenomenon. The improvement with ibuprofen supports the inflammatory nature of the lesions.
P: Prescribed oral ibuprofen 600 mg four times daily, which led to symptom improvement and resolution within a few weeks. Follow-up in two weeks confirmed complete resolution of symptoms. Advised to reach out if further issues or concerns arise.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that you've been transferred to our department with a diagnosis of unstable angina pectoris. You have CAD risk factors such as diabetes mellitus, smoking, and hypertension. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: We performed a percutaneous coronary intervention to address this issue. Our expert operator guided the attending physician, who has 3 years of interventional experience. We conducted a coronary angiography through your right radial artery, which showed a 70% occlusion in the proximal segment of your left main anterior coronary artery (LM) and a 90% occlusion in the proximal segment of the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD). 
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: We initially used a diagnostic catheter (6F TIG, TERUMO, Japan) which was withdrawn, and then advanced a hydrophilic guidewire (Merit Laureate; Merit Medical, USA). Unnoticed, it strayed into the distal right IMA. When the guiding catheter (6F EBU3.5, Medtronic, USA) was advanced over the guidewire, you complained of intolerable chest pain. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, I remember the chest pain.
Doctor: We immediately withdrew the guiding catheter and guidewire, then reintroduced the guidewire into the aortic sinus. We delivered the guiding catheter to the left coronary artery and performed balloon dilatation and stenting of the LM and LAD. During that time, you again complained of severe chest pain, and your blood pressure began to fall. 
Patient: Yeah, it was really painful.
Doctor: Your condition deteriorated despite the administration of opioid analgesics and intravenous fluids. We performed a transthoracic echocardiography to rule out cardiac tamponade and aortic dissection, which it did. 
Patient: What did you find then?
Doctor: Fluoroscopy suggested a right-sided pleural haemothorax (Fig. c). We conducted an IMA angiography that revealed obvious exudation of contrast in the third rib segment of the right IMA. To address this issue, we introduced a 2.0 mm × 15 mm semi-compliant balloon (MINI TREK, Abbott, IL, USA) up to the site of the leak and kept it inflated for 20 minutes to reduce the exudation.
Patient: Did it help?
Doctor: Yes, bleeding was finally staunched by embolization with coils (Fig). It's important for you to continue monitoring your symptoms and follow up with us as needed. We'll keep a close eye on your condition and work together to manage your CAD risk factors.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care, and please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any concerns or questions.
soap:
S: The patient, with a history of diabetes mellitus, smoking, and hypertension, presented with unstable angina pectoris. He reported severe chest pain during a percutaneous coronary intervention.
O: The coronary angiography revealed a 70% occlusion in the proximal segment of the left main anterior coronary artery and a 90% occlusion in the proximal segment of the left anterior descending coronary artery. Intervention included the use of a diagnostic catheter and a hydrophilic guidewire, followed by balloon dilatation and stenting. The patient experienced severe chest pain and hypotension during the procedure. Transthoracic echocardiography ruled out cardiac tamponade and aortic dissection. Fluoroscopy identified a right-sided pleural haemothorax. IMA angiography showed contrast exudation at the third rib segment of the right IMA, which was managed with a semi-compliant balloon and coil embolization.
A: The primary diagnosis is unstable angina pectoris complicated by a procedural iatrogenic right-sided pleural haemothorax. Differential diagnoses initially included cardiac tamponade and aortic dissection, which were ruled out by echocardiography.
P: The patient's management included withdrawal and repositioning of the catheter and guidewire, balloon dilatation, stenting, and embolization of the bleeding site. Ongoing management will focus on monitoring symptoms, managing CAD risk factors, and regular follow-ups to assess and address any further complications. The patient is advised to continue with prescribed medications, maintain a heart-healthy diet, and avoid smoking. Further consultations with cardiology and possibly a pulmonologist are recommended to ensure comprehensive care.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there! So, you've presented to our urology out-patient clinic with purulent discharge from the distal part of the dorsum of your penis. Can you tell me more about when this started?
Patient: Yeah, it started about 6 months ago after I had a circumcision at a different hospital.
Doctor: I see. And what's your medical and social history like? Any issues in the past?
Patient: No, nothing remarkable. I'm potty-trained and my developmental milestones and psychosocial status are all good.
Doctor: Great. And there's no consanguinity between your parents, right? No inherited diseases in the family?
Patient: That's correct, no issues there. My mom had an uneventful pregnancy with me too.
Doctor: Alright. So, you mentioned that various antibiotics were used to treat the purulent discharge, but it's been continuing for 6 months. Were there any complaints before the circumcision?
Patient: No, I didn't have any complaints before that.
Doctor: Upon admission, we recorded your temperature as 36.4 °C, pulse at 98 beats/minute, and blood pressure at 80/50 mmHg. Your condition was reported as superficial dorsal venous thrombosis, known as Mondor disease (MD), based on magnetic resonance imaging from the previous hospital. Our physical examination revealed a small pinhole lesion at the distal part of your penis and a rigid cylindrical tube extending to the proximal side of the penis.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: Now, in the laboratory analysis, your total white blood cell count was 6.1 × 103/mm3, hemoglobin was 13.2 g/dL, alanine aminotransferase was 19 u/l, aspartate aminotransferase was 21 u/l, and creatinine was 0.5 mg/dl. Your serological tests were negative for hepatitis B surface antigen (HbsAg), anti-hepatitis C virus (HCV), and anti-HIV.
Patient: That's good to know.
Doctor: Yes, it is. Your urine analysis showed normal amounts of red cells with suspicion of urinary tract infection. However, since you were treated with various antibiotics regimens, no bacterial growth was detected in the swab culture samples obtained from the fistula mouth.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: We also performed a genitourinary system ultrasonography which revealed no additional anomalies. Fistulography/sinography showed that there was no relationship between your urinary tract and the sinus.
Patient: So, what's the plan for treatment?
Doctor: In your case, we'll proceed with surgical exploration as the treatment for your condition. We'll continue to monitor your progress and adjust the treatment plan as needed.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me. I appreciate your help.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help.
soap:
S: The patient, a male who underwent circumcision 6 months ago, presents with persistent purulent discharge from the distal dorsum of the penis. He reports no prior complaints before the circumcision and has no significant medical or family history. He has been treated with various antibiotics without resolution of symptoms.
O: Vital signs upon admission were: temperature 36.4 °C, pulse 98 beats/minute, blood pressure 80/50 mmHg. Physical examination revealed a small pinhole lesion and a rigid cylindrical tube along the penis. Laboratory results showed WBC 6.1 × 10^3/mm^3, hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL, ALT 19 u/l, AST 21 u/l, creatinine 0.5 mg/dl. Serological tests for HBsAg, HCV, and HIV were negative. Urine analysis was normal with no bacterial growth in culture. MRI indicated superficial dorsal venous thrombosis (Mondor disease). Ultrasonography and fistulography confirmed no urinary tract involvement.
A: The primary diagnosis is Mondor disease with a complication of a persistent sinus tract post-circumcision. Differential diagnoses were considered but ruled out based on imaging and lab results.
P: The management plan includes surgical exploration to address the sinus tract. Post-operative monitoring and adjustment of treatment will be necessary based on the patient's recovery and response to the surgical intervention. Further antibiotic therapy will be guided by clinical progress and any new culture results.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you were referred to our hospital with suspected interstitial pneumonia in a health examination in 2013. How have you been feeling lately?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I have a slightly dry cough, but other than that, I've been feeling okay.
Doctor: Have you been experiencing any desaturation or difficulty breathing?
Patient: No, not really.
Doctor: I see. I noticed in your records that you've worked as a plasterer for more than 40 years. Did you use any protective equipment during your work?
Patient: No, I didn't use any protective equipment.
Doctor: Okay. During the examination, we performed chest auscultation and noticed slight bilateral inspiratory fine crackles in the bilateral lower lung zones. We also conducted a chest X-ray, which showed enlarged hilar lymph nodes and mild reticular opacities, mainly in the upper to middle lung fields of both lungs.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We performed a high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scan, which suggested a predominantly subpleural distribution of irregular linear opacities and reticulonodular shadows with interlobular septal thickening in both lung fields. However, your pulmonary function tests were close to normal, and your six-minute walking test during admission was also normal.
Patient: That's a relief, at least.
Doctor: In 2014, we noticed that your forced vital capacity (FVC) and diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) had decreased. The reticulonodular shadows on your HRCT scan had worsened as well.
Patient: But I haven't felt any worse in terms of my symptoms.
Doctor: That's interesting to note. Your thoracic symptoms had not deteriorated, and your vital signs remained stable. To establish a diagnosis, we performed VATS from the right S2 segment of the upper lung lobe and the right S9 segment of the lower lung lobe.
Patient: What did you find?
Doctor: We observed dense fibrosis with mononuclear cell infiltration and inorganic dust particles around the respiratory bronchioles in the upper lung lobe S2 segment, which is consistent with MDP. Additionally, we detected fibrously thickened interlobular septa and visceral pleura accompanied by dust, including some birefringent particles suggestive of silicates, and fibroblastic foci within these lesions.
Patient: And what about the lower lung lobe?
Doctor: In the lower lung lobe S9, we found extensive honeycomb changes with dilated bronchioles and parenchymal collapse, as well as fibroblastic foci within the cystic wall.
Patient: So, what does this all mean, Doctor?
Doctor: It means that your years of exposure to dust particles without proper protective equipment may have contributed to these findings in your lungs. We will need to monitor your condition closely and discuss potential treatment options to manage your symptoms and prevent further damage to your lungs.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap:
S: The patient, a former plasterer with over 40 years of experience and no history of using protective equipment, presents with a chief complaint of a dry cough. He denies experiencing desaturation or difficulty breathing. He was previously referred with suspected interstitial pneumonia in 2013.
O: Physical examination revealed slight bilateral inspiratory fine crackles in the lower lung zones. Chest X-ray showed enlarged hilar lymph nodes and mild reticular opacities in the upper to middle lung fields. HRCT scan indicated subpleural irregular linear opacities, reticulonodular shadows, and interlobular septal thickening in both lung fields. Pulmonary function tests were near normal, and a six-minute walking test was normal. VATS biopsy from the right upper and lower lung lobes showed dense fibrosis, mononuclear cell infiltration, inorganic dust particles, and fibroblastic foci, consistent with mixed dust pneumoconiosis (MDP).
A: The primary diagnosis is mixed dust pneumoconiosis, likely due to prolonged occupational exposure to dust without protective measures. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of interstitial lung disease, but the biopsy findings are highly suggestive of MDP. The prognosis depends on the progression of the lung disease and the effectiveness of the management plan.
P: The management plan will include regular monitoring of lung function and symptoms, pulmonary rehabilitation, and consideration of pharmacological treatment to manage symptoms and slow disease progression. The patient will be educated on the importance of avoiding further dust exposure and on recognizing symptoms of disease progression. Referrals to a pulmonologist and an occupational health specialist are recommended to optimize care and explore potential occupational disease compensation.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 59-year-old male who is scheduled for an elective open retropubic prostatectomy. This is because you have a benign enlarged prostate weighing approximately 65 grams. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I also see that your weight is 89 kg and you have an ASA physical status II. You were diagnosed with essential hypertension two years ago, and it's controlled with Ramipril 10 mg once daily. Are there any other morbidities or medications you're taking?
Patient: No, that's the only issue I have, and Ramipril is the only medication I take.
Doctor: Great. Your preoperative assessment did not reveal any other abnormalities related to anesthesia, and your vital signs were normal. You also stopped taking Ramipril for 48 hours before the operation, as advised. Your baseline laboratory results were normal, including your renal profile: creatinine 87 micromole/L, urea 7.9 mmol/L, Na 140 mmol/L, and K 4.1 mmol/L. 
Patient: Okay, so everything seems fine so far.
Doctor: Yes, it does. After discussing the anesthesia plan with you and the surgical team, it was decided to go with general anesthesia (GA) and postoperative patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) with morphine for pain management. 
Patient: Alright, I understand.
Doctor: The induction of GA was done using propofol (2mg/kg), fentanyl (100 micrograms), and rocuronium (0.6 mg/kg), followed by endotracheal intubation. We also inserted a radial arterial cannulation for IBP monitoring and two wide-bore peripheral cannulas (18G). 
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: However, during the induction, you experienced hypotension (BP dropped from 112/68 to 73/46) and bradycardia (HR dropped from 78/min. to 38/min.). We administered two successive 6 mg doses of ephedrine, which restored your BP and HR.
Patient: Oh, I see. Did everything go back to normal after that?
Doctor: Yes, your baseline arterial blood gas (ABG) after positioning was normal. At 2 hours into the surgery, the estimated blood loss was about 350 ml and the urinary output was 120 ml over the 2 hours. Your mean arterial pressure (MAP) was maintained above 70 mmHg without further vasopressors required, other than the initial 12 mg of ephedrine.
Patient: That's good to know.
Doctor: However, an arterial blood gas performed 2 hours after the start of surgery, done to monitor your haemoglobin level, showed that you had developed hyperkalaemia (6.1 mmol/L).
Patient: Oh no, what does that mean?
Doctor: Hyperkalaemia is a higher-than-normal level of potassium in the blood, which can cause complications if not managed properly. We will monitor and address this issue to ensure your safety.
Patient: Okay, thank you for letting me know.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will continue to monitor your condition and provide necessary care during your recovery. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.
Patient: I appreciate that. Thank you, doctor.
soap:
S: The patient is a 59-year-old male scheduled for an elective open retropubic prostatectomy due to benign prostatic hyperplasia with a prostate weight of approximately 65 grams. He reports controlled essential hypertension treated with Ramipril 10 mg daily, which was stopped 48 hours prior to surgery. No other morbidities or medications were reported.
O: Preoperative assessment showed normal vital signs and laboratory results, including creatinine 87 micromole/L, urea 7.9 mmol/L, Na 140 mmol/L, and K 4.1 mmol/L. During induction of general anesthesia, the patient experienced hypotension (BP dropped to 73/46) and bradycardia (HR dropped to 38/min), which were corrected with ephedrine. Estimated blood loss during surgery was 350 ml, and urinary output was 120 ml over 2 hours. An arterial blood gas performed 2 hours into the surgery revealed hyperkalaemia (K 6.1 mmol/L).
A: The primary diagnosis is benign prostatic hyperplasia. The patient experienced intraoperative hypotension and bradycardia, likely related to anesthesia, which responded to ephedrine. He also developed hyperkalaemia during surgery, which needs to be monitored and managed.
P: Continue to monitor vital signs and electrolytes closely, particularly potassium levels. Manage hyperkalaemia as per standard protocols. Postoperative pain management includes patient-controlled analgesia with morphine. The patient should resume Ramipril as advised postoperatively, considering his hypertension history. Provide patient education on signs of complications and ensure follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any arising issues.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that your younger sister is 41 years old and a housewife, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I see that she is considered obese according to the Japanese criteria, with a height of 156 cm and weighing 69.6 kg. Her waist circumference is 102 cm and her visceral fat area is 164.2 cm2, calculated employing abdominal CT. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: It appears that she has had slightly impaired fasting glucose levels on her medical check-ups for the past 3 years, but she hasn't consulted a doctor about this issue. Is that right?
Patient: Yes, she didn't consult any doctor about it.
Doctor: I also noticed that she has experienced repeated falls and injuries for the past 5-6 years. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, she has been falling and getting injured quite often in recent years.
Doctor: Your sister married at the age of 37 and underwent infertility treatment. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's true.
Doctor: When she was admitted for detailed examination to our hospital, she showed distal muscle weakness of the four extremities, handgrip myotonia, and distal muscle atrophy, which are consistent with the characteristics of DM1. Were you aware of this?
Patient: Yes, we were informed about that.
Doctor: Her laboratory data showed elevated fasting glucose levels with dyslipidemia, which met the Japanese criteria for metabolic syndrome (MetS). An oral glucose tolerance test using 75 grams of glucose showed impaired glucose tolerance (IGT). As a result, we started treatment with diet and exercise. Are you following the prescribed treatment plan?
Patient: Yes, she has been following the diet and exercise plan.
Doctor: Due to the presence of MetS, we conducted a sleep study using an apnomonitor Type 4. The apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) was quite high at 55.9, indicating severe sleep apnea syndrome (SAS) with an AHI of 30 or more. However, there were no signs of snoring, apneic episodes, nocturnal dyspnea, or daytime somnolence. Were you aware of her sleep issues?
Patient: No, we didn't know about her sleep issues until now.
Doctor: Her arterial blood gas (ABG) test showed hypoxia accompanied by hypercapnia. Furthermore, her lung function test, using spirometry, revealed a decreased percent predicted vital capacity. This indicates some issues with her respiratory system. We will need to monitor and address this as part of her treatment plan.
Patient: I see. Thank you for informing us about this. We will make sure to follow up on her treatment and monitor her condition closely.
Doctor: You're welcome. It's important to keep a close eye on her health and follow the recommended treatment plan. If you have any concerns or notice any changes in her condition, please don't hesitate to contact us.
soap:
S: The patient's younger sister, a 41-year-old housewife, is obese with a history of slightly impaired fasting glucose levels for the past 3 years, which were not previously addressed with a doctor. She has experienced repeated falls and injuries over the last 5-6 years and has undergone infertility treatment. She has been following a prescribed diet and exercise plan for metabolic syndrome (MetS) and impaired glucose tolerance (IGT).
O: The patient's sister has a height of 156 cm, weight of 69.6 kg, waist circumference of 102 cm, and visceral fat area of 164.2 cm2. She exhibits distal muscle weakness, handgrip myotonia, and distal muscle atrophy, indicative of DM1. Laboratory data show elevated fasting glucose levels and dyslipidemia. An oral glucose tolerance test confirmed IGT. A sleep study revealed severe sleep apnea syndrome (AHI 55.9) without typical symptoms like snoring or daytime somnolence. Arterial blood gas test indicated hypoxia with hypercapnia, and spirometry showed reduced vital capacity.
A: Primary diagnosis is DM1 with complications including MetS, IGT, severe sleep apnea syndrome, and respiratory dysfunction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of muscle weakness and metabolic abnormalities.
P: Continue with the current diet and exercise regimen. Initiate treatment for sleep apnea, possibly including CPAP therapy. Monitor respiratory function and consider pulmonary rehabilitation if necessary. Regular follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and progression of symptoms. Educate the patient and family on the importance of adherence to treatment plans and monitoring health status.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you were brought to the emergency department following a car accident. Can you tell me what happened?
Patient: Yeah, I was stepping into a car when a 5-ton water tanker rolled over my lower body.
Doctor: That sounds serious. We assessed your condition when you arrived. Your Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was 15, with a pulse rate of 80 beats per minute and your blood pressure was 90/60 mmHg. We noticed profuse bleeding due to a perineum injury. Did you experience any pain in your head or neck?
Patient: No, I didn't feel any pain there.
Doctor: That's good to know. We performed X-rays and found no fractures of the skull, cervical spine, and pelvis. We also performed urinary catheterization without difficulty, and there was no hematuria. We conducted an abdominal ultrasound, and it didn't show any internal bleeding. After stabilizing you with fluid and blood replacement, we took you to the operating theatre for injury assessment.
Patient: What did you find during the surgery?
Doctor: While you were placed in the lithotomy position, we observed anterior displacement of the anus and a circular skin defect surrounding the region. There was 1 cm of normal perianal skin left, with no actual skin loss. We performed a digital and proctoscopy examination which showed an intact anorectum and surrounding sphincters.
Patient: What about the wound?
Doctor: Upon exploring the wound, we found a complete disruption of the posterior pelvic floor with lateral extensions into both gluteal regions and your right thigh. We could even pass a hand behind the rectum and into the sacral promontory. The case was associated with extensive venous bleeding, but there was an absence of major arterial tears.
Patient: How did you manage that?
Doctor: We managed it by inserting multiple packs and partially closing the skin defect. We also made a small incision to perform a defunctioning sigmoid colostomy. There was no intra-abdominal bleeding reported. We removed the packs two days later without any bleeding complications.
Patient: How much blood did I need?
Doctor: During the first 48 hours of your admission, you required a total of 22 units of blood.
Patient: Is there anything I should know about my recovery?
Doctor: We will be conducting continuous follow-up examinations to monitor your progress. It's important that you attend these appointments and let us know if you experience any issues or discomfort. We'll be here to support you throughout your recovery.
Patient's Family: Thank you, doctor. We appreciate all the care you have provided and will make sure he follows up with all appointments and instructions.
soap:
S: The patient, a victim of a traumatic accident involving a 5-ton water tanker rolling over his lower body, reports no head or neck pain. He was conscious and alert with a GCS of 15 upon arrival at the emergency department.
O: Initial assessment showed a pulse rate of 80 bpm and blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. Profuse bleeding from a perineum injury was noted. X-rays revealed no fractures in the skull, cervical spine, or pelvis. Urinary catheterization was performed successfully without evidence of hematuria. Abdominal ultrasound showed no internal bleeding. Surgical findings included anterior displacement of the anus, a circular skin defect around the perineum, complete disruption of the posterior pelvic floor with lateral extensions into both gluteal regions and the right thigh, but no major arterial tears. The patient required 22 units of blood within the first 48 hours.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe trauma to the pelvic region with extensive damage to the posterior pelvic floor and associated structures, managed surgically with wound exploration, packing, partial skin closure, and a defunctioning sigmoid colostomy. No internal organ damage or major arterial injury was identified.
P: The patient will undergo continuous follow-up examinations to monitor recovery and manage any complications from the trauma and surgeries. It is crucial for the patient to attend all follow-up appointments and report any discomfort or issues. The patient and his family have been advised of the importance of compliance with the treatment and follow-up plan to support recovery.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you were admitted to Chongqing Shapingba District Chenjiaqiao hospital. Can you tell me what happened?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I suffered fractures of my left femoral neck after falling to the ground.
Doctor: I see. (Looking at Fig. a) It appears you had a left total hip replacement on July 16, 2017, and the X-ray (Fig. b) shows a prosthetic hip in position. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: After the surgery, you were given Cefazolin sodium (1 g IV q8h) for prophylactic administration, and your indwelling urinary catheter was removed after 24 hours. Can you tell me how you felt after surgery?
Patient: I felt okay initially, but on the 8th day after surgery, I started to experience left hip pain and some other symptoms.
Doctor: What were those symptoms, if you don't mind me asking?
Patient: I had a fever of 38.5 °C, redness and swelling around the surgical site (Fig. c), and I also reported local tenderness.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. It seems your blood examination demonstrated an increase in white blood cell (WBC), C-reactive protein (CRP), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) during the postoperative period. We also conducted screening tests for human immunodeficiency virus, hepatitis B virus, and hepatitis C virus infections, which were non-reactive. There was no abnormality in your liver or renal function tests, and your T-lymphocyte subsets and gamma-globulin analysis were within the normal range.
Patient: Okay, so what happened next?
Doctor: On July 25, 2017, approximately 400-ml of light-yellow, odorless subcutaneous fluid was punctured at your surgical site and sent to the microbiological laboratory for bacterial smear and culture. While a large amount of polymorphonuclear leucocytes (PMNs) were detected, no microorganism was found on gram-staining smear. Moreover, there was a negative growth on the blood and chocolate agar plates.
Patient: What about the repeated blood cultures?
Doctor: The repeated blood cultures using the BacT/ALERT 3D blood culture microbial detection system were also negative. Despite these results, a post-surgical infection was still under suspicion. The wound was cleaned with iodophor and drainage. 
Patient: Alright, thank you for the information, doctor. What should I do now for follow-up care?
Doctor: It's important to monitor your symptoms closely and report any changes or worsening of your condition. Keep the surgical site clean and follow any recommendations provided by your healthcare team. If you notice any redness, swelling, or increased pain, please contact your doctor immediately.
soap:
S: The patient, who previously underwent a left total hip replacement in 2017, presented with complaints of left hip pain starting on the 8th day post-surgery. He also reported a fever of 38.5 °C, redness, swelling, and local tenderness around the surgical site.
O: Examination findings included elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate, indicating inflammation. Imaging confirmed the position of the prosthetic hip. Approximately 400-ml of light-yellow, odorless subcutaneous fluid was aspirated from the surgical site, showing a large amount of polymorphonuclear leucocytes but no microbial growth on gram stain or culture. Repeated blood cultures were negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is suspected post-surgical infection of the left hip despite negative microbial cultures, possibly due to the presence of polymorphonuclear leucocytes and clinical symptoms of infection. Differential diagnoses could include non-infectious post-surgical inflammation or a reaction to the prosthetic material.
P: The patient is advised to maintain strict hygiene and monitor the surgical site closely for any signs of worsening infection. Regular follow-up with the healthcare team is essential to manage symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. Immediate medical attention should be sought for any increase in redness, swelling, or pain. Further diagnostic tests may be required if symptoms persist or worsen.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've presented with a history of low backache for the past one year. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've had typical claudication symptoms, left-sided numbness, and paresthesia of the foot. But I don't have any radicular pain.
Doctor: I see. Have you noticed any changes in your symptoms over time?
Patient: Yes, there has been a progressive reduction in claudication distance. Also, my gait suddenly got worse, and I started experiencing urinary incontinence after a trivial fall last week.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Let me share some findings from your examination. You have a bilateral high-stepping gait due to foot drop, symmetrical weakness of both the L4 and L5 roots (MRC grade 0/5), and partial weakness of the S1 root (MRC grade 3/5). You also have nondermatomal sensory disturbances and absent deep tendon reflexes in your lower limbs. Your anal tone is normal, but saddle anesthesia is present. 
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We performed a postvoidal ultrasonogram of your urinary bladder and found a residual urine volume of 250 ml, confirming a neurogenic bladder. We also conducted plain radiography of your lumbar spine, but it didn't show any gross feature of instability and was inconclusive. 
Patient: So, what's the issue then?
Doctor: We did a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of your lumbar spine and found a solitary intraspinal posterior epidural lesion of 1.8 × 1.5 × 0.5 cm at the L2-L3 level. There's also adjacent epidural fatty hypertrophy contributing to severe canal stenosis (3 mm). Your cauda equina is severely compressed and almost not visible.
Patient: That sounds serious. Was anything else found?
Doctor: Yes, we performed computerized topography (CT) and discovered an osseous lesion attached to the right L2 inferior articular process, causing severe secondary canal stenosis. Due to your recent-onset neurological deficit, we advise you to undergo surgical decompression and excision biopsy at the earliest.
Patient: Alright, what will the procedure be like?
Doctor: You'll be positioned prone on a Relton Hall frame under general anesthesia. We'll employ a standard midline posterior approach, expose your L2 and L3 lamina, and remove the spinous process. Then, we'll perform the surgical decompression and excision biopsy.
Patient: Okay, I understand. Thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll do our best to help you through this process. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out.
soap:
S: Patient reports a history of low backache for the past year, progressive reduction in claudication distance, worsening gait, left-sided numbness, paresthesia of the foot, and recent onset of urinary incontinence following a trivial fall. No radicular pain is reported.
O: Examination reveals bilateral high-stepping gait, symmetrical weakness of both L4 and L5 roots (MRC grade 0/5), partial weakness of S1 root (MRC grade 3/5), nondermatomal sensory disturbances, and absent deep tendon reflexes in lower limbs. Saddle anesthesia is present, anal tone is normal. Postvoidal ultrasonogram shows a residual urine volume of 250 ml, indicating a neurogenic bladder. Lumbar spine radiography was inconclusive. MRI of lumbar spine shows a solitary intraspinal posterior epidural lesion at L2-L3 (1.8 × 1.5 × 0.5 cm) with severe canal stenosis (3 mm) and severe compression of cauda equina. CT reveals an osseous lesion attached to the right L2 inferior articular process causing severe secondary canal stenosis.
A: Primary diagnosis is severe spinal canal stenosis at L2-L3 due to an epidural lesion and osseous growth, resulting in cauda equina syndrome. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurogenic claudication and urinary incontinence, but imaging and symptoms strongly support the current diagnosis.
P: Plan includes urgent surgical decompression and excision biopsy of the lesion. The procedure will involve general anesthesia, positioning on a Relton Hall frame, and a standard midline posterior approach to expose and operate on L2 and L3. Postoperative care will include monitoring of neurological function and bladder management. Referral to a neurosurgeon has been made, and patient education regarding the procedure and expected outcomes has been provided. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and any further intervention needed.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've been admitted for the evaluation of heavy proteinuria, deteriorating renal function, and severe hypertension. Can you tell me about your medical history?
Patient: Yes, I was diagnosed with RA when I was 42. I also had a left vitrectomy for retinal detachment and bilateral femoral head replacement after a fracture when I was 49. I have drug allergies to many drugs.
Doctor: I see. Due to your drug allergies, various treatments for RA were introduced, including methotrexate, infliximab, etanercept, salazosulfapyridine, leflunomide, bucillamine, tacrolimus, abatacept, and tocilizumab, in addition to prednisolone and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: You were treated with 2 to 3 mg/day of tacrolimus, which is the standard dose for RA, in addition to 8 mg/day of prednisolone from the age of 48 for 2 years and 3 months. After the introduction of tacrolimus, can you tell me if there were any changes in your blood pressure?
Patient: Yes, my BP increased from 120/70 mmHg to 140/80 mmHg after 20 months of tacrolimus treatment.
Doctor: I see. During that time, the trough levels of tacrolimus were within acceptable ranges between 5 and 10 ng/dL. Proteinuria began to increase from the baseline proteinuria of 0.3 to 0.5 g/g creatinine 24 months after tacrolimus treatment, but your serum creatinine level was sustained around 0.8 mg/dL. Due to uncontrolled arthritis of RA, tacrolimus and tocilizumab were changed to tofacitinib citrate 27 months after starting tacrolimus treatment. Were there any issues with tofacitinib citrate?
Patient: Yeah, I had an allergic reaction to it, so we discontinued it after just 2 months.
Doctor: I understand. Proteinuria further increased after the discontinuation of tacrolimus and tocilizumab, and then severe hypertension at 190/100 mmHg and progressive renal dysfunction developed. A 40 mg telmisartan/5 mg amlodipine besilate combination tablet was introduced 2 months after tacrolimus discontinuation. Did you notice any changes in your condition after that?
Patient: Not really, my renal function continued to deteriorate and my creatinine level went up to 2.63 mg/dL.
Doctor: That's concerning. You were admitted to our hospital 3 months after discontinuing tacrolimus for further evaluation and treatment. Upon admission, your body temperature was 36.5°C and your height was 154 cm. We will closely monitor your condition and work on finding the most appropriate treatment for you.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I'm glad to be here and hope we can find a solution soon.
soap:
S: The patient, a 52-year-old with a history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) diagnosed at age 42, reports heavy proteinuria, deteriorating renal function, and severe hypertension. The patient has a history of left vitrectomy, bilateral femoral head replacement, and multiple drug allergies. The patient experienced an increase in blood pressure and proteinuria following tacrolimus treatment, which was discontinued due to uncontrolled RA symptoms and replaced with tofacitinib citrate. However, the patient had an allergic reaction to tofacitinib citrate, leading to its discontinuation. The patient's condition did not improve with the introduction of a 40 mg telmisartan/5 mg amlodipine besilate combination tablet, and renal function continued to deteriorate.
O: Upon admission, vital signs included a blood pressure of 190/100 mmHg and a body temperature of 36.5°C. The patient's height was recorded at 154 cm. Previous treatments included tacrolimus (2-3 mg/day) and prednisolone (8 mg/day), with tacrolimus trough levels maintained between 5 and 10 ng/dL. Proteinuria increased from a baseline of 0.3 to 0.5 g/g creatinine, and serum creatinine levels rose to 2.63 mg/dL.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe hypertension and deteriorating renal function secondary to RA and its treatment. Differential diagnoses may include drug-induced nephropathy and RA-related renal complications. The prognosis is guarded due to the progressive nature of the renal dysfunction and the complexity of managing RA with multiple drug allergies.
P: The management plan will include close monitoring of renal function and blood pressure. Adjustments to the current antihypertensive regimen may be necessary, and further evaluation to assess the extent of renal damage is planned. A consultation with a nephrologist will be arranged to explore additional therapeutic options. Patient education will focus on understanding the relationship between RA management and renal health, and strategies to minimize further renal damage. Compliance with the new treatment regimen will be emphasized, and alternative RA treatments will be considered given the patient's history of drug allergies.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi doctor, I came here because I have been experiencing abdominal pain and distention.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me a bit about your medical history? Have you had any surgeries or major illnesses?
Patient: Well, I had a uterine myomectomy 17 years ago, but that's about it. I don't smoke or drink alcohol.
Doctor: Okay. Let's check your vitals. On admission, you don't have a fever, your body temperature is 37.5° C, your pulse rate is 70 beats/minute, and your blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. We will also perform a neurological examination and some laboratory tests.
Patient: Sure, no problem.
(After the tests)
Doctor: Your neurological examination and laboratory test results, including complete blood count and liver and renal function, are all within normal limits. Now, let's do a physical examination.
(After the physical examination)
Doctor: Your physical examination showed a distended abdomen with a large tumor extending from the pelvis to the umbilical area. We'll need to do a computed tomographic (CT) scan to get more information.
Patient: Oh, okay. I hope it's not something serious.
(After the CT scan)
Doctor: The CT scan revealed a 14-cm uterine malignant tumor. Additionally, there is a 4-cm isolated splenic nodule suggesting a metastatic lesion. The good news is that the tumor is limited to the uterus and does not extend beyond.
Patient: Oh no, what do we do now?
Doctor: You will need to undergo radical surgical treatment. This will include a total hysterectomy, total splenectomy, and lymphadenectomy.
Patient: I understand. I'm ready to do whatever it takes to get better.
(After the surgery)
Doctor: The surgery was successful. We removed a huge, whitish, friable tumor occupying the entire uterine cavity, as well as a 4-cm splenic nodule with irregular contours and a heterogeneous aspect. The histopathological analysis showed that you have uterine clear cell carcinoma invading the outer half of the myometrium with negative lymph nodes.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that the cancer is classified as stage IB according to the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics classification scheme. The tumor cells do not have estrogen and progesterone receptors but are positive for cytokeratin AE1/AE3.
Patient: And what about the splenic lesion?
Doctor: The splenic lesion consisted of multiple confluent and variably sized fibrotic nodules centered by many vessels. These vessels were surrounded by areas of hemorrhage, fibroblasts, and hemosiderin-laden macrophages.
Patient: So, what's the next step for my treatment?
Doctor: We will closely monitor your condition and discuss further treatment options, if necessary. It's important to follow up regularly with your healthcare team to ensure the best possible outcome.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I really appreciate your help and guidance.
soap:
S: The patient, a female with a history of uterine myomectomy 17 years ago, presents with abdominal pain and distention. She denies smoking and alcohol consumption.
O: Vital signs on admission were normal with a body temperature of 37.5° C, pulse rate of 70 beats/minute, and blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg. Neurological examination and laboratory tests including complete blood count, liver, and renal function were within normal limits. Physical examination revealed a distended abdomen with a large tumor extending from the pelvis to the umbilical area. CT scan showed a 14-cm uterine malignant tumor and a 4-cm isolated splenic nodule suggestive of a metastatic lesion. Post-surgical histopathological analysis confirmed uterine clear cell carcinoma invading the outer half of the myometrium with negative lymph nodes, and the splenic lesion consisted of fibrotic nodules with hemorrhage and hemosiderin-laden macrophages.
A: The primary diagnosis is uterine clear cell carcinoma, stage IB, with a splenic lesion consisting of fibrotic nodules. The tumor is limited to the uterus with no extension beyond, and lymph nodes are negative. Differential diagnosis would consider other forms of uterine malignancies and metastatic diseases.
P: The patient underwent a successful radical surgical treatment including total hysterectomy, total splenectomy, and lymphadenectomy. The plan includes close monitoring and regular follow-ups to assess for any further treatment needs. Education on the importance of follow-up care and potential signs of recurrence will be provided to ensure compliance and optimal management of her condition.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I see from your past medical history that you have diabetes. What brings you to the emergency department today?
Patient: Well, I've had this left eye pain for the past two days, and now I've got this weird rash on the left side of my neck.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you describe the pain you've been experiencing?
Patient: It's been intermittent, but when it comes, it's like a shooting, burning pain along the rash.
Doctor: Alright, let me examine the rash. It appears to be nonconfluent grouped vesicles on the posterior neck. Based on my examination, I'm diagnosing you with herpes zoster reactivation, or shingles. We'll perform an electrocardiography (EKG) to check for any blocks or evidence of pericarditis. 
Patient: Oh, okay. So, what's the treatment for this?
Doctor: We'll treat you with valacyclovir and oral steroids. It's also important that you seek urgent ophthalmological evaluation at a specialized center.
Patient: Got it, thanks.
*Some time later*
Doctor: I see you were readmitted in March 2018 with altered mental status. At that time, a new EKG showed a first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block. Your admission vitals were a blood pressure of 96/58 and heart rate of 65 beats per minute. 
Patient: Yeah, I remember that.
Doctor: The laboratory studies done on admission were mostly unremarkable except for hypoglycemia at 32. Later that day, you developed bradycardia at 49 beats per minute with a blood pressure of 117/63 mm Hg. A repeat EKG showed a Second Degree AV block (Mobitz I).
Patient: Hmm, that sounds serious.
Doctor: It's important that we monitor it closely. Did you have any fever, chills, arthralgias, myalgias, vomiting, or diarrhea during that time?
Patient: No, I didn't have any of those symptoms.
Doctor: And what about chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath?
Patient: No, none of those either.
Doctor: That's good. We corrected your electrolyte abnormalities and continuously monitored you on telemetry, and followed with serial EKGs. You had a positive chronotropic response with exertion and awakening. An echocardiography done during admission showed preserved left ventricular function (60%) with no wall motion abnormalities and mild grade 1 diastolic dysfunction.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: We'll have an electrophysiology evaluation, and they've advised outpatient monitoring within two weeks to evaluate for progression. You're not considered to be at high risk of progression due to the preservation of your left ventricular function, but it's important to keep an eye on it.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me.
soap:
S: The patient, a known diabetic, presents with left eye pain and a rash on the left side of the neck, described as intermittent, shooting, and burning, coinciding with the rash. The patient was previously admitted with altered mental status and a first-degree AV block, later progressing to a second-degree AV block (Mobitz I).
O: Physical examination revealed nonconfluent grouped vesicles on the posterior neck, consistent with herpes zoster. Initial vital signs during a past admission included a blood pressure of 96/58 mm Hg, heart rate of 65 bpm, which later changed to 117/63 mm Hg and 49 bpm, respectively. Laboratory studies noted hypoglycemia at 32. Echocardiography showed preserved left ventricular function at 60% with mild grade 1 diastolic dysfunction. No fever, chills, arthralgias, myalgias, vomiting, diarrhea, chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath were reported.
A: Primary diagnosis is herpes zoster reactivation. The patient also has a history of cardiac conduction abnormalities, specifically a progression from a first-degree AV block to a second-degree AV block (Mobitz I), with preserved left ventricular function and mild diastolic dysfunction. No acute systemic symptoms were noted.
P: Initiate treatment with valacyclovir and oral steroids for herpes zoster. Urgent ophthalmological evaluation is recommended due to the proximity of the rash to the eye. Continuous cardiac monitoring and serial EKGs are advised due to past cardiac issues. An electrophysiology evaluation and outpatient monitoring within two weeks are planned to assess for progression of AV block. Educate the patient on the importance of monitoring symptoms and adhering to follow-up appointments.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've presented your one-year-old son to the emergency department. What seems to be the problem?
Patient's Parent: Hi, doctor. My son suddenly has this severe edema on his right eyelid, making it impossible for him to open his right eye.
Doctor: I see, let me perform an ophthalmologic examination. It appears that there's painful eyelid edema along with conjunctival chemosis. Due to the extensive eyelid swelling, it's not possible for me to examine his pupillary light reflexes or ocular motility nor perform a fundus examination. Has he had a fever lately?
Patient's Parent: Yes, he had a temperature up to 39.1°C.
Doctor: Alright. Upon physical examination, your son seems alert and doesn't show any neurological or meningeal signs. However, I notice that he has cutaneous varicella lesions spread over his entire body. Has he received his vaccination for varicella yet?
Patient's Parent: No, he hasn't. We were planning to get it between the age of 12 to 15 months.
Doctor: I see. His laboratory workup shows normal leukocytes (9.23 x 103/µl), thrombocytopenia with platelets at 67 x 103/µl, and elevated CRP (52 mg/l). The clinical examination can't exclude orbital cellulitis, and there are multiple enlarged lymph nodes in his neck region. We suspect a secondary bacterial infection of the cutaneous varicella lesions around the eyelid. We'll perform a CT of the orbit to investigate further.
Patient's Parent: What did the CT scan show, doctor?
Doctor: The CT scan revealed pronounced superficial soft tissue inflammation of the right periorbit without evidence of an intraorbital inflammation or abscess formation, cavernous sinus thrombosis, or intracranial extension of the inflammation.
Doctor: We'll need to hospitalize your son for a trial of intravenous antiviral (acyclovir) and antibiotic therapy (amikacin, flucloxacillin, and ceftriaxone). We'll monitor his progress and adjust the treatment as needed.
Patient's Parent: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: After two days, we noticed a poor clinical response to the initial antibiotic therapy, with increasing swelling of his left eyelid as well. So, we changed the antibiotic therapy to clindamycin.
Patient's Parent: Is there anything else we need to do for his varicella infection?
Doctor: In immunocompetent children, varicella-zoster virus (VZV) usually causes a benign infection without the need for systemic antiviral treatment. However, in this case, we decided to treat the varicella infection with intravenous acyclovir for 5 days (30 mg/kg/day in 3 divided doses).
Patient's Parent: How are his laboratory markers now?
Doctor: His laboratory markers of inflammation have increased, with a maximal leucocytosis of 23.8 x 103/µl and a CRP level. We'll continue to monitor his progress and make any necessary adjustments to his treatment plan.
Patient's Parent: Thank you, doctor. We appreciate your help in treating our son.
soap:
S: The patient, a one-year-old male, presented with severe right eyelid edema, conjunctival chemosis, and inability to open the right eye. The parent reported a recent fever peaking at 39.1°C and noted the presence of cutaneous varicella lesions over the entire body. The child has not yet received the varicella vaccine.
O: Physical examination revealed alertness with no neurological or meningeal signs, but multiple enlarged lymph nodes in the neck region were noted. Laboratory findings included normal leukocytes at 9.23 x 10^3/µl, thrombocytopenia with platelets at 67 x 10^3/µl, and elevated CRP at 52 mg/l. CT scan of the orbit showed pronounced superficial soft tissue inflammation of the right periorbit without intraorbital inflammation, abscess, cavernous sinus thrombosis, or intracranial extension. Initial antibiotic therapy showed poor response, prompting a switch to clindamycin. Laboratory markers later showed increased leucocytosis at 23.8 x 10^3/µl and elevated CRP.
A: Primary diagnosis is secondary bacterial infection of cutaneous varicella lesions around the eyelid, with differential diagnoses including orbital cellulitis. The presence of varicella-zoster virus infection complicates the clinical picture.
P: The patient was hospitalized for intravenous antiviral therapy with acyclovir (30 mg/kg/day in 3 divided doses for 5 days) and antibiotic therapy including amikacin, flucloxacillin, ceftriaxone, and later clindamycin due to poor initial response. Continuous monitoring of clinical response and laboratory markers is planned, with adjustments to treatment as necessary. Education provided to the parent regarding the nature of the infection and the importance of vaccination.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've presented with dyspnea, headache, and lower extremity edema for the past three weeks. Can you tell me more about these symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've been having trouble breathing, especially when I'm doing something or moving around. The headaches come and go, and my legs have been swelling up.
Doctor: I see. We've done some initial labs, and they show marked leukocytosis with increased myeloid precursors and rare blasts: white blood cell count of 156 k/μL, neutrophils 103 k/μL, monocytes 7.1 k/μL, eosinophils 1.6 k/μL, basophils 0, and blasts 12 k/μL. Other cell lines are normal with hemoglobin of 12.6 gm/dL and platelets of 242 k/μL. Your uric acid was elevated at 9.0 ml/dL, and lactate dehydrogenase was 860 units/L.
Patient: Hmm, okay. What does that all mean?
Doctor: Based on these results, we performed a bone marrow biopsy, which revealed a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm. The biopsy showed marked hypercellularity (99%) with profound myeloid hyperplasia and complete maturation to segmented neutrophils. Immature myeloid cells of all stages were appropriately present, without dysplasia or increased blasts. A moderate amount of reticulin fibrosis was seen.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: Additionally, Giemsa stain of the aspirate confirmed the biopsy findings with a blast count of less than 5%. By flow cytometric analysis, myeloid cells in the blast gate expressing CD34 accounted for less than 1% of total cells. Molecular diagnostic testing of the aspirate indicated the presence of the BCL-ABL1 p210-type transcript by RT-PCR with an international scale-normalized (ISN) copy number of 35.27%. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) testing for BCR-ABL1 fusion was present in 89% of cells. Together, these findings are consistent with a diagnosis of chronic phase-CML.
Patient: So I have chronic phase-CML?
Doctor: Yes, that's correct. Considering your symptoms of intermittent dyspnea in the absence of anemia, we conducted further evaluation. A stress echocardiogram indicated a normal left ventricular ejection fraction.
Patient: That's good, I guess.
Doctor: We also performed a computed tomography (CT) chest with contrast enhancement, which revealed mediastinal, cervical, and supraclavicular adenopathy, without evidence of pulmonary embolism.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: The next step is for you to undergo an excisional biopsy of the cervical adenopathy to further assess the situation and determine the best course of treatment.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll schedule the biopsy and keep you informed of the results and treatment options. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out.
Patient: Thanks, I appreciate it.
soap:
S: The patient reports experiencing dyspnea, particularly with activity, intermittent headaches, and lower extremity edema over the past three weeks.
O: Vital signs were not provided. Lab results indicate marked leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 156 k/μL (normal: 4.5-11 k/μL), neutrophils 103 k/μL, monocytes 7.1 k/μL, eosinophils 1.6 k/μL, basophils 0, and blasts 12 k/μL. Hemoglobin is 12.6 gm/dL (normal: 13.8-17.2 gm/dL for men, 12.1-15.1 gm/dL for women), and platelets are 242 k/μL (normal: 150-450 k/μL). Uric acid is elevated at 9.0 mg/dL (normal: 3.5-7.2 mg/dL for men, 2.6-6.0 mg/dL for women), and lactate dehydrogenase is 860 units/L (normal: 140-280 units/L). Bone marrow biopsy shows chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm with marked hypercellularity and myeloid hyperplasia. Molecular diagnostics indicate BCL-ABL1 p210-type transcript by RT-PCR with an ISN copy number of 35.27% and BCR-ABL1 fusion in 89% of cells by FISH. Stress echocardiogram shows normal left ventricular ejection fraction. CT chest with contrast reveals mediastinal, cervical, and supraclavicular adenopathy, no pulmonary embolism.
A: The primary diagnosis is chronic phase chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) based on lab findings, molecular diagnostics, and bone marrow biopsy. Differential diagnosis includes other myeloproliferative disorders, but these are less likely given the specific molecular findings.
P: Plan to perform an excisional biopsy of the cervical adenopathy to further evaluate the extent of disease and refine treatment options. Initiate treatment for CML, likely including tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs), and monitor response to therapy. Address symptoms of dyspnea, headache, and edema with supportive care as needed. Schedule follow-up appointments to monitor treatment progress and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on the nature of CML, treatment expectations, and importance of adherence to therapy.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing intermittent fever with chills and rigors for about 2 months now. I've also had night sweats, loss of appetite, and loss of weight.
Doctor: I see. Have you noticed any other symptoms during this time? Any rashes or skin changes?
Patient: Yes, I had a transient macular rash at the onset of the fever, but it resolved on its own without any treatment.
Doctor: Okay, have you experienced any swelling or pain in your lymph nodes?
Patient: Yes, I've had generalized lymphadenopathy in my cervical, axillary, and inguinal regions for about a month. They became extremely painful a few days prior to my presentation.
Doctor: Have you had any joint pain or swelling?
Patient: I've had synovitis in my lower limb small joints, which progressed to lower limb large joints and eventually to my upper limb small and large joints over the last 3 days.
Doctor: Do you have any past history or family history of arthritis?
Patient: No, I don't have any history of arthritis and my past medical history is unremarkable.
Doctor: Can you tell me about your occupation and lifestyle? Have you been exposed to any toxic environmental conditions or engaged in promiscuous sexual behavior?
Patient: I work as a mason, but I haven't been exposed to any toxic conditions that I know of. I don't have any promiscuous sexual behavior, I don't consume alcohol, and I don't smoke tobacco.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. On examination, you appear emaciated, febrile, and pale. I can feel bilateral, firm, matted lymph nodes of varying sizes, about 2-3 cm, in your cervical, axillary, and inguinal regions, which are tender. There's also tender hepatosplenomegaly. We'll need to run some tests to better understand what's going on.
(After running the tests)
Doctor: Your laboratory investigations show high white cell counts with normocytic anemia. Your platelets are within the normal range. Your inflammatory markers are high and have been in a rising trend since the onset of arthritis. Your liver and renal functions are normal. Your rheumatoid factor, anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide, anti-nuclear antibodies, HIV 1 and 2 antibodies, Epstein-Barr virus IgG, and immunoglobulin G tests are all negative.
Patient: So, what does this mean, doctor?
Doctor: Based on your symptoms and test results, we need to consider several possible causes for your condition. We'll continue monitoring your condition and may need to run additional tests to determine the best course of treatment. In the meantime, it's important to rest and maintain a healthy diet to help your body recover.
Patient: Alright, thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll be in touch soon with further instructions. Take care.
soap:
S: The patient, a mason, presents with a 2-month history of intermittent fever, chills, rigors, night sweats, loss of appetite, and weight loss. He reports a transient macular rash at the onset of the fever and generalized painful lymphadenopathy in cervical, axillary, and inguinal regions for about a month. He also describes progressive synovitis affecting both small and large joints of the lower and upper limbs over the last 3 days. The patient denies any past or family history of arthritis, exposure to toxic environmental conditions, promiscuous sexual behavior, alcohol consumption, or tobacco use.
O: Physical examination reveals an emaciated, febrile, and pale patient. Palpation identifies bilateral, firm, matted lymph nodes of 2-3 cm in cervical, axillary, and inguinal regions, tender to touch, and tender hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory investigations show high white cell counts, normocytic anemia, normal platelet count, elevated inflammatory markers, and normal liver and renal functions. Tests for rheumatoid factor, anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide, anti-nuclear antibodies, HIV 1 and 2 antibodies, Epstein-Barr virus IgG, and immunoglobulin G are negative.
A: The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest a systemic inflammatory process possibly due to an infectious or autoimmune etiology, given the exclusion of common rheumatologic and viral causes. Differential diagnoses include atypical infections, lymphoproliferative disorders, or other systemic inflammatory disorders.
P: Plan to continue monitoring the patient's condition with additional diagnostic tests to further narrow down the causes. Recommend rest and a healthy diet to support recovery. Schedule a follow-up appointment for review of additional test results and adjustment of the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the management plan and maintaining regular follow-up appointments.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've been referred to the Medical Genetic Centre of Guangdong Women and Children Hospital for prenatal diagnosis due to imbalanced development of your twins. Can you tell me more about your pregnancy and medical history?
Patient: Yeah, I'm 26 years old, and this is my first pregnancy. I got pregnant naturally, and I have no family history of twins or multiple births. There haven't been any remarkable abnormalities in my medical history.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. We performed some fetal ultrasound scans on your pregnancy. The scans showed a monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy with imbalanced development of the twins. Twin 1 presented with normal development of the brain, abdomen, skeleton, and cardiovascular system. Twin 2 had a normal brain and abdomen, but there were some issues like an underdeveloped or absent radius, a ventricular septal defect, and a cleft lip and palate.
Patient: Oh, that's concerning. What about the ultrasound parameters for both twins?
Doctor: For Twin 1, the Biparietal diameter (BPD) was 59 mm, Head circumference (HC) was 223 mm, Abdominal circumference (AC) was 198 mm, Femur length (FL) was 45 mm, and Heart rate (HR) was 154/min. For Twin 2, the BPD was 51 mm, HC was 192 mm, AC was 141 mm, FL was 35 mm, and HR was 141/min.
Patient: I see. What do you think could be the cause of the imbalanced development?
Doctor: The data from the ultrasound examination indicated that the imbalanced development of the two fetuses might be due to Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), but we can't exclude the possibility of chromosomal abnormalities.
Patient: What are the next steps then?
Doctor: After discussing with our genetic counseling team, we recommend that you and your partner consider a diagnostic amniocentesis for the normal fetus, Twin 1. This will help us determine if there are any chromosomal abnormalities.
Patient: Okay, we agreed to do the amniocentesis. What will be done with the amniotic cells?
Doctor: The amniotic cells will be cultured in CHANG Medium for 7-10 days for karyotyping and Comparative Genomic Hybridization (aCGH) analysis. Conventional G-banded karyotyping will be performed on peripheral blood lymphocytes and cord blood according to standard protocols. We will use Agilent's commercial arrays for the aCGH analysis and the data will be analyzed with AgilentGen.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything. We'll follow your recommendations and hope for the best outcome for our twins.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will keep you updated on the results and guide you through the next steps based on the findings. Take care, and don't hesitate to contact us if you have any questions or concerns.
soap:
S: The patient, a 26-year-old female in her first pregnancy, reports no significant personal or family medical history, including no history of twins or multiple births. She presents for prenatal diagnosis due to imbalanced development of monochorionic diamniotic twins, identified during routine fetal ultrasound.
O: Fetal ultrasound shows Twin 1 with normal development (BPD 59 mm, HC 223 mm, AC 198 mm, FL 45 mm, HR 154/min) and Twin 2 with several abnormalities including an underdeveloped or absent radius, ventricular septal defect, and cleft lip and palate (BPD 51 mm, HC 192 mm, AC 141 mm, FL 35 mm, HR 141/min). The imbalanced development raises concerns for Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) and potential chromosomal abnormalities.
A: Primary assessment suggests a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy with significant developmental imbalance possibly due to TTTS, though chromosomal abnormalities cannot be excluded. Differential diagnosis includes genetic syndromes that could explain the physical anomalies in Twin 2.
P: Plan includes performing diagnostic amniocentesis on Twin 1 to check for chromosomal abnormalities using CHANG Medium culture, karyotyping, and aCGH analysis. Results will guide further management. The patient and her partner have consented to this procedure. Continuous monitoring of the pregnancy and fetal development will be necessary, with further genetic counseling based on amniocentesis results.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're on a regimen of steroids for either Behçet's disease or systemic lupus erythematosus. What brings you in today?
Patient: Yeah, I've been feeling really unwell lately. I've had a fever, cough, and my breathing has been getting worse over the past week.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Do you have any other medical history I should be aware of?
Patient: I had a small bowel resection for intestinal necrosis a while back and have been on parenteral nutrition since then.
Doctor: Thank you for that information. Let's check your vitals. Hmm, you're presenting with a fever of 39.1°C, tachycardia of 116/min, and hypoxia with an oxygen saturation of 94% in a nasal oxygen cannula. I also hear a grade 3/6 regurgitant diastolic murmur in your left third intercostal space during auscultation. 
Patient: Oh no, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: Unfortunately, you've fallen into respiratory failure. We'll need to support you with mechanical ventilation immediately. Your PaO2/FiO2 ratio is calculated as 105, which is quite low. We've also done chest radiography and computed tomography, which revealed diffuse extensive consolidation in both lung fields, corresponding with diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH).
Patient: So what does that mean?
Doctor: The diagnosis was confirmed by bronchoalveolar lavage, which showed increasing bloody secretions in three consecutive aliquots. Additionally, a peripheral blood examination revealed a white blood cell count of 11,540/mm3, hemoglobin of 6.6 g/dL, and platelet count of 132,000/mm3. Your aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase, and lactate dehydrogenase levels were 18, 16, and 164 IU/L, respectively.
Patient: Are my kidneys okay?
Doctor: Your renal function is slightly affected, with a creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL. Your C-reactive protein is elevated to 12.3 mg/dL. Blood cultures afterward grew Staphylococcus warneri.
Patient: What does the echocardiography show?
Doctor: Echocardiography revealed aortic regurgitation and a mobile vegetation measuring 15 × 9 mm on the commissure between the left and right coronary cusps. Your left ventricular function is preserved, with an ejection fraction of 62%.
Patient: So what's the diagnosis?
Doctor: You've been diagnosed with bacterial endocarditis, which is complicated by respiratory distress related to the DAH.
Patient: Can I have surgery to fix this?
Doctor: At this point, you're judged not to tolerate cardiac surgery due to the exacerbating bleeding and respiratory failure related to heparinized extracorporeal circulation. We'll need to come up with a different management plan.
Patient: What's the plan then?
Doctor: We will discuss the best course of action with your medical team and inform you and your family of the decisions made. Your treatment and recovery are our top priority.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
soap:
S: The patient reports feeling unwell with symptoms of fever, cough, and worsening breathing over the past week. The patient has a history of a small bowel resection for intestinal necrosis and is currently on parenteral nutrition. The patient is also on a regimen of steroids for either Behçet's disease or systemic lupus erythematosus.
O: Vital signs include a fever of 39.1°C, tachycardia at 116/min, and hypoxia with an oxygen saturation of 94% on nasal cannula. Physical examination reveals a grade 3/6 regurgitant diastolic murmur in the left third intercostal space. Laboratory findings show a white blood cell count of 11,540/mm3, hemoglobin of 6.6 g/dL, platelet count of 132,000/mm3, AST 18 IU/L, ALT 16 IU/L, LDH 164 IU/L, creatinine 1.5 mg/dL, and CRP 12.3 mg/dL. Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus warneri. Imaging includes chest radiography and CT showing diffuse extensive consolidation in both lung fields, indicative of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. Echocardiography revealed aortic regurgitation and a mobile vegetation measuring 15 × 9 mm on the commissure between the left and right coronary cusps, with preserved left ventricular function (EF 62%).
A: The primary diagnosis is bacterial endocarditis complicated by respiratory distress related to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. Differential diagnoses include exacerbations of underlying autoimmune disorders such as Behçet's disease or systemic lupus erythematosus. The patient's condition is further complicated by previous intestinal surgery and dependency on parenteral nutrition.
P: Immediate management includes supportive care with mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. Antibiotic therapy tailored to culture results (Staphylococcus warneri) is necessary. Cardiac surgery is currently contraindicated due to high risks associated with the patient's current unstable condition. Continuous monitoring of cardiac and respiratory status is essential, and adjustments to the treatment plan will be discussed with the medical team and communicated to the patient and family. Further consultations with cardiology, infectious disease specialists, and a nutritionist are planned to address the complex needs of the patient.

dialogue:
Patient: Hi doctor, I came to the emergency room because my leg pain has been getting worse.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: Well, I have peripheral artery disease and iron deficiency anemia.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Let's first check your hemoglobin level. I'll order some initial laboratory tests.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: Your hemoglobin level came back unexpectedly low at 5.4 g/dl. We gave you three units of packed red blood cells, and your hemoglobin level increased to 6.9 g/dl. I'm going to consult our gastroenterology department for an evaluation of possible gastrointestinal bleeding.
Patient: I see. But I haven't noticed any hematochezia, melena, hematemesis, fatigue, or abdominal pain.
Doctor: That's good to know. Have you been taking any iron supplementation?
Patient: Yes, I've been taking oral iron supplements for the last five years.
Doctor: And have you had any previous upper and lower endoscopies?
Patient: Yes, I've had both, and they were negative.
Doctor: Thank you. On physical examination, I noticed you have pale conjunctivae. Your abdomen is soft and non-tender, and there are no masses, organomegaly, or vascular bruits detected. Your vital signs are stable, and your laboratory results show a hemoglobin level of 6.9 g/dL, a mean corpuscular volume of 73.5, and a hematocrit level of 22.7% with normal white blood cell and platelet counts.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: Your iron-deficiency anemia analysis shows ferritin levels of 6 ng/mL, serum iron levels of 25 μg/dL, total iron-binding capacity of 535 μg/dL, and transferrin saturation of 5%. We performed an upper and lower endoscopy, which showed no active bleeding or suspicious lesions.
Patient: That's a relief.
Doctor: We then performed a small bowel capsule endoscopy and found a suspicious lesion in your jejunum with evidence of fresh blood. To investigate further, we did a double balloon enteroscopy and discovered a 25mm proximal jejunal soft submucosal mass with mild superficial ulceration/erosions of the surface mucosa.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We took biopsy samples from the mass and will refer you for further management and surgical evaluation. The final pathology results revealed a cavernous hemangioma without any evidence of malignancy.
Patient: That's good to hear. Thank you, doctor, for taking care of me.
Doctor: You're welcome. Keep an eye on your symptoms and follow up with your surgeon for further guidance on managing the hemangioma.
soap:
S: The patient, with a history of peripheral artery disease and iron deficiency anemia, presented to the emergency room complaining of worsening leg pain. The patient has been on oral iron supplements for five years and has had no recent symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding such as hematochezia, melena, hematemesis, fatigue, or abdominal pain. Previous upper and lower endoscopies were negative.
O: Initial hemoglobin was critically low at 5.4 g/dl, prompting transfusion of three units of packed red blood cells, raising the level to 6.9 g/dl. Physical examination revealed pale conjunctivae, a soft and non-tender abdomen with no masses, organomegaly, or vascular bruits. Vital signs were stable. Laboratory results showed a mean corpuscular volume of 73.5, hematocrit of 22.7%, with normal white blood cell and platelet counts. Iron studies indicated severe iron deficiency with ferritin at 6 ng/mL, serum iron at 25 μg/dL, total iron-binding capacity at 535 μg/dL, and transferrin saturation at 5%. Capsule endoscopy identified a suspicious lesion in the jejunum, confirmed by double balloon enteroscopy as a 25mm jejunal soft submucosal mass with superficial ulceration. Biopsy confirmed a cavernous hemangioma.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe iron deficiency anemia secondary to bleeding from a jejunal cavernous hemangioma. Differential diagnosis initially included gastrointestinal bleeding from other sources, but investigations have ruled out other common etiologies.
P: The patient received an initial transfusion and stabilization of hemoglobin levels. Gastroenterology consultation led to the identification and biopsy of the jejunal lesion. The patient will be referred for surgical evaluation and management of the cavernous hemangioma. Continued iron supplementation is recommended, along with close monitoring of hemoglobin and iron levels. Follow-up with a surgeon is necessary to discuss potential surgical removal of the hemangioma and to prevent further complications from bleeding.

dialogue:
